Posts.Title: Is the cold cap worth it and chemo questions

Posts.Content: hey Rebecca, I am now 4 days into my first cycle of chemo. And I have opted against the cold cap, because I just couldn't be fussed with the trauma of holding on!  I am also loving my showers just now - I feel a real need to feel fresh, and so i am showering - using shampoo and just going about life as much as normal. I guess, if you are trying to keep your hair, then you need to stop with all the hair care whilst it is still there...  I am enjoying seeing my short crop in the mirror, as I feel I know it's just a matter of time.  Wig is not an option for me, just doesn't feel right to me, and I heard they may become itchy when the scalp feels sore as well. I opted to go shopping for head scarves - and I must admit I splashed out: went to All Saints! Nice, elegant, feels very comfortable! And then there are endless websites, where you can see how to drape the scarf around your head - I expect, as a model, you will already be well informed and able!  Bottom line: go with what feels right! Don't be brave, and don't be miserable! there are enough reasons for misery without adding anything extra. ;)  As for the chemo: they only need to reach your arm, and your BP. I'd advise on remembering a book and your iPod! Mine took 2 hours (at home) and I was soooooo bored! lol Dorothee xx

Posts.Title: New member

Posts.Content: hey Fretty, I feel I need to put a little word in edgeways, as I am reading Sandra's well meaning words. I am all about holistic! Because not only has our body taken a beating, but so has our mind, our soul! And I reckon the medics are wonderful at putting the treatments out there for our physical recovery. But our mental wounds are gaping wide open during the process, and usually long after.  I wholeheartedly agree that we need support in mending our mental, psychological bruises and wounds as much as the physical aspect. I am very much looking at active peer support in my community for just that reason. Because it is bloody tough going it alone!  But, unless I am totally misunderstanding Sandra's message - I do not believe for one minute, that your cancer has returned because you have been emotionally unwell before. I would even go as far as saying, that tack doesn't help! I don't believe looking at past traumas, when you are dealing with present ones is necessarily the right time. And feeling guilt about not having addressed past issues just now just focussed the little energy you have, all in the wrong direction.  You have done nothing wrong, and this is most probably just sheer pot luck! It bloody sucks!  I think I made my point. Sorry, to be so direct today.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Reoccurance

Posts.Content: hi Andrey, you have my deepest sympathy. Not being physically close, and having a different health service local to your mum-in-law makes everything much more difficult.  It is such a shame that she hasn't felt able to confide in you much sooner. I am sure it will make you feel even more helpless right now, and possibly frustrated for time and opportunity missed.  You may however need to consider that your mother-in-law made her choice to protect her family, and she may only now feel that she is running out of steam to cope on her own, or running out of options to cope on her own.  My first port of call would still be your mother-in-law. I think you need to find out from her how she feels about her situation, and then you need to work with her.  Although this News is undoubtedly a very new and recent shock to you and your family, in actual fact, it isn't so for her. She has been living with her diagnosis now for, as you say, about 6 years. She will have put a lot of coping strategies into place for herself during this time.  I think what you need in the first place is a certain diagnosis! And I imagine she can have that over in Russia as well as over here. - I take it she is Russian, and so, visiting a doctor in her own home certainly is an advantage for her because of language.  Have you considered going over there, instead? I know this can be difficult for work etc, but maybe she could do with someone over there who can come along to her initial consultations. To ask all the right questions, and make her see she is not left on her own.  Once you have a diagnosis, then the next step might be to have a chat about what that means to her, and what that means to you and the family. - Is she scared of die-ing, or is she scared of making you suffer?!  It would also then be a good idea to talk to the health professionals over there, to compare what they can offer her in way of treatment, and what she could expect over here.  It's not easy. My dad had cancer in Germany. And although that was a lot closer, in the end, the distance really was irrelevant. I was happy about the health service, but I wasn't entirely familiar with it. Bottom line though, we worked with him! In his situation. Asking all the way along,what he would like to do.  I wish you all the best, and like it's been said already, you may want to give the Macland nurses a call on this. They may give you some more concrete advice and support.  Hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: What to do ... my mother in law

Posts.Content: hey Jenny, There are probably a hundred and one good reasons why we feel lumps from now on. I Like the first one, it is always important to have them checked out. Posts.Title: How would money help?

Posts.Content: Good morning everyone,  Those of you who know me might also know that, after I completed the chemo-bootcamp and the radiotherapy-tanning in December 2012, I set myself a new challenge in January 2013: I was going to get running!  This turned out to have been a rather ambitious undertaking, as I started running with Herceptin, and a heart tablet, because the valve in my heart was under pressure. But, come Race for Life in June 2013, I entered the 10k. And I managed it, with puffing and panting, and running and walking.  I have been going out there pounding the pavements, buying shoes and lycra, and I have managed to increase the running times, slowly but very surely. From 3 minutes running interspersed with a minute walking, to running for about a half hour now. So, now I just wanted to share with you my huge pleasure: Yesterday I ran the whole 10k, start to finish! 1Hour 05 Minutes. Herceptin and heart tablet are long left behind. And I do feel I have more energy than I have had in a very long time! - well maybe not exactly today ... today I can feel every muscle! hahaha.  As some of you are struggling through your bootcamps and tannings at the mo, I would like to shine a little sparkle into your world of hopes and dreams for your future. It's sheer determination - all the way! So, here is to being determined! Dorothee xx

Posts.Content: Hey Carla, Yes, it can be very confusing.  Let me start by saying: no cancer journey is the same, because we are all different in the way we live, in the way we respond to treatments and in the way our body and mind is able to cope. There are also many different types of cancers, so even when they look the same from the outside, they may well be different in their make-up and ability to cause havoc.  And then you do get different medical teams around the country and internationally making different choices on treatment.  There appears to be a pretty common theme though: the more aggressive the cancer cells multiply, the more aggressive the treatment. So, if you are graded at 3, then you are more likely getting chemo offered. And then there is a size issue: if it's small and local, then you are less likely getting the whole works.  So, it really seems individually different. And you need to work it out with your medical team, and with your family maybe, to figure what is right for you! Other people's 'stories' don't necessarily help you here. Hopefully you have a great rapport with your oncologist, and learn to trust his judgement. And then you always have a chance to tweak the treatment as you go along.  There is no hard and fast rule to this, there are professionals who know what they are doing medically. And then there is you, who has to benefit from the treatment, both medically and very much emotionally. And it is the emotional battle which seems to push us to our limits more than anything.  Dorothee xx

Posts.Content: Hey Babs, I haven't read any of the suggested literature, so don't know whether I am just going to repeat what has already been said.  My angle on this is that I imagine you are suffering with something like post traumatic stress! I think what we have experienced comes close to a car crash! Out of the blue, devastating, life changing! And then you are left with the scars, and you are meant to just get back into the car and drive on as if nothing had happened!  It takes some people years and years to get through such an ordeal! And the first step to recovery seems to me to be the acknowledgement that we are not able to function and cope as we think we should.  I am wondering whether you live with fears and threats, which you may not even be totally aware of, but which haunt you during the night, and which leave you feeling uneasy. If that is the case, then maybe they need addressing, so that you can relax again in your own skin, so to speak.  This post traumatic period is a time to readjust, isn't it?! Finding your own confidence again, trusting your own body again to do what it is meant to be doing: supporting you to LIVE!  I'd go to the GP with the suggestion of PTS, and see what his suggestion is to tackle that.  Dorothee xx

Posts.Title: FEELING SO DOWN

Posts.Content: Hi Roxiroo,  Yeah, this is BIG! Very scary when you get diagnosed. And so much waiting to be done to figure what exactly the medics are dealing with, and only then will you start to get some idea of what your treatment plan will entail!  Good News is though, that Breast Cancer in most cases is treatable! The research is so far advanced these days that the treatment gets to be very specific, very targeted. And the chances of making a good recovery are very good!  I am glad you have found yourself here amongst us. People here really do know what it's like, and more so they are living examples that it can all be done! It's gonna be tough, but it's doable!  My suggestion for now: Take it one step at a time. Don't look at the massive mountain which needs to be climbed, look at one step at a time. And that means, concentrate on meeting with your medical team, learn to trust they know what they are doing, and hand over control to them.  Any questions, and rants, all is welcome! And it will hopefully help you get to grips with what is happening.  Big hugs,  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Just been diagnosed and feeling numb

Posts.Content: Hey, yeah, that sounds familiar!  I try and drink 2 litres of fluids a day to flush stuff through - and I struggle like mad for the first 3 days after chemo. I am just running my 3rd round, also FEC.  I don't like water, so that's a no-no, but, the first few days peppermint tea, and fruit teas with honey seem okay. So is flat coke.  Milk is the main ingredient for me during week 2 - loads in teas and cereals. Remember, eating a bowl of cornflakes, which is nice and bland, with a heap of milk will make up fluids, too.  I also use cordials, but when I do, I just put in a tiny amount to flavour. And then I go for del Monte dark juices, but you can't get them everywhere any more. Might have to hunt those out in smaller shops.  Hope that helps. But, yeah, it is a struggle!  Dorothee xx

Posts.Content: Hi, Sorry to hear you are entering boot camp, too! - Worst bit is the time of diagnosis I think. When all of this is terribly new, horribly real and yet you have no idea about anything.  I remember spending the night after my diagnosis on my sofa, just shaking and crying. As soon as I got a date for my op, though, things began to change. that resilience in me started to kick in, and I started to feel less vulnerable, and more in control.  The doc wouldn't start on any treatment though, until he had all the results back and got the whole picture of me. That was a try looooong wait. And it felt like the cancer was spreading every second to new areas in my body. - That is not the case. Yes, it spreads, but not half as fast as we think it does. So, let them make all the assessments first, it's worth it in the long run. And then go for chemo! Loads of us are going through it just now, and there is plenty of support here.  Dorothee xx

Posts.Content: I too am on th Wockhardt tamoxifen, and I am fine so far.  As for the joint pains. Go see your GP and find out whether the x-rays can be speeded up?  In the meantime, maybe the good old fashioned hot and cold bathing might stimulate the blood flow. And putting your feet up is good for circulation too.  Big hugs, hope things improve for you soon. Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen and Joint Pain

Posts.Content: Right, this might not be much of a diet plan for anyone here, but tbh, I think we need to include the thought of exercise here, too.  With having all these meds and ops and waiting times etc I think it is only natural that we are tired, and lethargic and would like to just cuddle up in a lovely cosy blanket.  And this winter weather is not helping the thought of going out there - have another chocolate instead. But NOOO! Get the wellies out, extra socks on and go for long walks!  Diet on it's own just doesn't work, ladies, not in the long run. You cannot starve your body off food, because all it does is go into famine mode, and then at the end of it it compensates by putting it on even more. And all the weight lost is usually water!  Now for real fat loss you need to 'burn' the fat. And that is done with exercise, not dieting. All the dieting weight you will otherwise loose is muscle! And that will make you feel weak. And to build muscles you need to eat proteins.  Sorry guys, you probably all know what I am saying. And I know its not straight forward to loose the weight. Just thought I put my thoughts out there, too.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: how to lose weight on tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Hey honey, A big , big hug from me too. Scary times again. And since you have been there once before, I think all that scary feeling from the first time round just comes straight back to haunt you once more.  Lets look at this though: You have got pain, and you are feeling lousy. That's not a good state to be in! And from your oncologist point of view, he will be looking at this from the perspective of: it's not Nothing! So, let's figure out what we are dealing with.  Our worst nightmare is 'it's spread', that's why that comes in as not only our first reasoned choice, but our only one! And yet, there are other good reasons out there! All this medication can well be playing havoc with your body.  Your doctor is not necessarily anticipating serious problems, but neither is he gambling! He is just very good at his job! Get it looked at asap!  Yes, scary time. And it doesn't help that lovely people around you feel they want to be kept on the safe side of life, and they are willing you to be well! That's so not helping you! Because even if there is nothing physically to be found, your reaction of your fear shows that you are feeling very vulnerable, and very fragile in your soul and mental well-being! And it's not all about bones and bits and pieces, it's about your well-being!  I am so sorry you feel you are not able to share your worries at home. You certainly can here! You have every right to feel how you do, and you need support in this, rather than trying to support an air of wellness! Be yourself! Be scared! But trust that you have medical people around you, who are doing their best to make sure they catch whatever it is as soon as!  We are all here, waiting alongside you! But in the end of the day, you need to know what's going on! If only to settle the fear of the unknown!  Dorothee xx

Posts.Title: Cravings

Posts.Content: Hi, I remember all too well sitting opposite my surgeon when he told me my results: malignant and aggressive. And on top of that he said, it's been there for months and you may as well go on your holidays now, because we are not doing anything until we have the biopsy back, which will take another 10 days ... and then it took another week before surgery on top of that! VERY VERY scary time. I felt so invaded - and soooo ready to just go under the knife there and then and have it all taken out of me. And all I could do was go on holiday and WAIT! - Felt like shouting 'wait for what? Wait to die? If you aren't quick enough, then that biopsy thing isn't gonna help!'  But, I am still alive and kicking! It was the time on my holiday that I had reflections on my worries: I very consciously looked at why I was frightened, and I have come to the very conscious realisation that I love living! And that has become my mantra since! Finding a strong point within yourself, that hook, which you can pull yourself up on, that's important, and it's real! As you go through Boot Camp, you are doing that FOR YOURSELF!  As for 'being positive for them', I think you need to be HONEST - with them and with yourself! Honesty is least draining to your own well-being. And I was surprised how disarming my honesty could be to my loved ones. My mum is still so upset at having lost my dad now three years ago to cancer. And I first thought of needing to be gentle with her. But I have found, she is actually not just coping with my sense of reality, but she is also able to reflect on her own journey again with my dad, and it is helping her, too. Fear and pain IS reality to this shit! It needs to be dealt with, carefully but honestly!  And Sassy: I will be thinking of you tomorrow!!!! Like all the rest of us here!!!! We'll be here, not going anywhere too fast! Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Post-surgery results and treatment plan ...

Posts.Content: That word 'control' resonates in my ears! - I need control, and I have found in this journey, that the only control I seem to have, is to let everything be as it comes. It seems a strange paradox: Giving up control in order to gain it.  Every day is different for me at the moment, both physically and mentally, and that's been the case now for months. And I can't seem to just say 'tomorrow I will ...', because tomorrow is unexpectedly a totally different kettle of fish.  I can see how you feel you are pushing people away - but then you are not pushing everyone away. Here for example you are opening yourself up very bravely and you are inviting others , like myself, to share a bit of your journey.  It's just, that you have to do this with a bit of control and a bit of personal space! I think the need for my personal space has increased. I feel myself reminded of dirty dancing: this is my space - this is yours etc.  I feel it is because we are so vulnerable in our own thoughts, that coping with others isn't quite so easy. When I have a good spell I am quite relaxed about others asking me how I am. Come the middle week of chemo though and you keep getting those texts .... I am ready to delete my contacts, even my mother! Maybe especially my mother, lol! It would be okay if she told me nice things, but she just texts, or calls and wants to know how I am - well, I KNOW how I am, and it's not good, and I don't need to be sharing that. I would be in much need of some positive stimulating alternatives!!!  I don't think anyone in their right minds should see your need for more personal space as offensive! I believe it is your natural body defence system kicking in hard to preserve energies for that internal battle, which, after all is quite draining. Keep battling! Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: out of control and scared

Posts.Content: hey Amber, Although we seem to be having a very one sided discussion here, I am sure there are lots of women out there who are not having any weight issues with Tamoxifen. I imagine this medication is a bit like the pill. Some people put on weight with the pill. Problem with hormone induced tactics is that when the weight creeps up we don't much like it, because we live in a society where overweight is not much accepted. Slimmer looking is still so much more the in thing.  Apart from that, there are health issues which we are made aware of. But then, Tamoxifen is actually a kind of 'life-saver'. So, what will it be? I feel I am happy on Tamoxifen, because it is recommended by my specialists. So then I need to have a think about, what do I do about the possible weight gain. I will be as active as I can be, as healthy as I can be. Within reason, and within the enjoyment that I get out of it. Leading a healthy balanced life is exactly that: it's a case of careful balancing! Or juggling without dropping everything. But bottom line for me is: I have to see the advantage of it! Otherwise there is no point! Life is about living! Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: how to lose weight on tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Keeping fingers crossed for you. hope you know more soon, and can start anticipating the next stage of your treatment.  Hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Appointment today

Posts.Content: Tax is sooooo taxing! You feel like you have been in the battle zone, because you HAVE been in the battle zone!  Last one? Well, my thoughts are:  if you are weighing up short term grottiness with long term health prospect, then I would take the short term shit, have it done with and know I have done everything in my power.  However, if the question should be weighing up long term side effects/ long term damage due to having the last tax, then that's more tricky, because you have quality of life to consider.  It sounds like a good idea to have a long chat with your oncologist before you make up your mind. Maybe he can give you some idea as to how important that last tax is. Unfortunately we haven't got a crystal ball, so my thoughts are: get yourself informed, but then listen to your own body, and make the choice which feels right for YOU! Hope you find your way through this struggle.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Don't want last taxotere but will I regret it?

Posts.Content: HAD! When I woke up from my anaesthetic, and my surgeon said all was out. That's when I stopped HAVING cancer!  All the stuff after was prophylactic!  Funnily, as such, most of the time I HAD cancer, I didn't even know I did ...  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: HAD or HAVE?

Posts.Content: Hey, I am just looking at this from the perspective of 'purpose':  Radiotherapy would be useful only if there was breast tissue left to be zapped, I guess. Since you have been given a mastectomy they are probably certain (hahaha, that sounds evasive!) that all possible affected breast tissue is removed in that area.  as for chemo, I know I was borderline. Whereas my surgeon said nothing needed doing, my oncologist insisted on the bootcamp approach. And I know how unsettled you must be feeling right now. It probably still feels to you like you haven't thrown everything possible at it, because when we hear cancer, we automatically associate that with chemotherapy as the choice treatment.  But take heart that your doctors know what's best for you! treatment has come a long way, and maybe the burden that chemo puts on your body would right now outweigh it's possible effectiveness.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: No further treatment....worried!

Posts.Content: Hey Mudge,  I have a 'no regret' speech for this occasion! (sorry anyone who has heard it before).  I was in a similar position, and I did go for the bootcamp option. I had 6 cycles of FEC. It is what it says on the tin! It's not a walk in the park. But it is doable. And personally it's given me some peace of mind.  My decision was, under the circumstances of having very little control in any of this, that I would trust my medical team. And like your situation, my surgeon thought the tanning was good enough, but my oncologist wanted to throw the kitchen sink at it! And so we started throwing! - No regret.  Out the other end, I think we will always have this paranoia hanging over us. I don't think a day goes by when I don't frantically check for lumps, imaginary or otherwise. Having been moved into the category of 'it has happened', that curtain of obliviousness has lifted forever. We are so much more aware.  So, in the end it's the best choice FOR YOU which you have to consider! And no regrets! That doesn't necessarily mean going for the bootcamp option, it means digging deep, looking at your own pros and cons. There are no guarantees, either way. It's a tough one. And again, we are making decisions of great magnitude with our backs against the wall.  Talk it through with your family, and in the end, trust your own instincts, and your medical team!!  And if you go through bootcamp, then we are all here to support you every step of the way!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Chemo decision. Yes or no?

Posts.Content: My dad had non hotchkins lymphoma. A very aggressive very invasive cancer. His chemo worked very well for him. When I first got told of his diagnosis I thought he wouldn't make 6 months. He proved us all so wrong! He was up and walking the Swiss Alps 6 months on!  Yes, it took its toll after 5 years, but then my dad was 78 years old and his aging body just wasn't able to fight any more. There comes a point.  But during those 5 years he LIVED!!! There were hurdles to climb, but he would look out the window and enjoy what he saw. Loved to work on his computer, loved to be around his grandchildren.  I think there is more than Hope - there is Living! Right here, right now!  I don't envy you for your tough times ahead, but maybe courage and life enable you to look beyond the crevices.  And as for night times - nothing helped me more than a good book! It's those dark, quiet hours which are the worst.  Hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed. Please someone reassure me

Posts.Content: Oh Pat, that is wonderful News!!!! We all need some of that! May I join you for that toast on New Year's to everyone here who has still a mountain to climb, and to all who have climbed already. Hold on tight to your rope, ladies!!!!  hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: To Infinity & Beyyyyyyond !!

Posts.Content: Hey, Favourite cafe and ice-cream milkshake ... yeah!!! Good on you.  That's the first one out of the way!!!! Count them off and celebrate after! That way you get rid of some of their nasty memory too.  Yes, you are amazing! But bootcamp on Christmas Eve really does suck. Hope you can enjoy the next couple of weeks now. Big hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: First Docetaxel

Posts.Content: hi Joysivercat, this waiting is tough. But at least there are things in motion now to find out exactly what is going on. It would be silly for us to try and reassure you that there is nothing, because, the one thing you do know is that there is Something. You just don't know yet what that something is.  You should have a breast care nurse assigned to you. Is she nice? She might be able to talk you through some of your results and the tests which you are about to have as well.  I am so sorry you are having to find yourself in this very uncertain state of mind. It is nasty, and very scary. But I am glad you have found your way here to share your fears with us. There are loads of folk here who have worried and do currently worry about what's going on.  Please feel free to keep posting. Let us share your waiting time with you.  Hugs Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Failed mammogram and bowel screening in the same month!

Posts.Content: Hi, as I understand it, the thought behind it is that massages etc invigorate the body, and with that the lymphatic system.  Chemo is given with the understanding that cancer cells may still be harboured around the body. And they could be carried around on the lymph system.  Having just read my own writing though, I am puzzled too: if your chemo has been successfully completed then there should be no more cancer cells around!  The other reason for keeping massages gentle is the healing around the site of your affected area.  Would be good to get more of a satisfactory answer though! I had the same problem with the local beauty salon after completion of the chemo cycle. I was told the ladies were not qualified to work on me for about 5 years. And I was having to look around for specially trained complementary therapists. You will be able to find those when you ask the BC nurse, or a cancer charity service.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Chemo and spa treatments

Posts.Content: that sucks! Your BC nurse should be your pal! I despair! - As you will know the system inside-out, you will be aware of who you can go see instead! Your GP maybe?  It will be very interesting to get others' personal experience on this.  In the meantime, I would go with an antihistamine! That surely can't harm you!  And then you can ring the nurses on this site as well! They can't give you very personal info, but they are very good at chatting through general medical points.  Good luck  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: The blue dye area on my breast very irritable and stingy !!

Posts.Content: Hi,  Oh dear, that sounds to me like maybe you have an allergic reaction to the dye. Have you spoken with your BC nurse about it? I wonder whether you may be able to take an antihistamine. If you cannot get in touch with anyone today, see if you can do first thing in the morning.  Otherwise, do you use any cream? Very carefully maybe try something like E45.  Well done for getting through your op though! That's one step out of the way already!  Hope you are enjoying your Christmas anyway.  Hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: The blue dye area on my breast very irritable and stingy !!

Posts.Content: Hey congenial, always good to find a reason to go clothes shopping. - But,  I am not sure whether anything but time is going to give you your answer.  Do you think that you are going to be put on hormone treatment after your chemo? If that is the case, then scroll back a few pages on this discussion forum, because we have just had a long debate on how to loose weight on Tamoxifen.  It also depends on how much you WANT to loose that weight again. If you are happy the way you are, then, I think just go with the flow and buy bigger.  As an interim, you could buy in a couple of cheaper items in the short run. And box up those trousers that are a bit too tight. Put them in the loft rather than to the charity shop, and wait and see.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Weight?

Posts.Content: Cancer Research UK have got a bit more insight here   Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Chemo and spa treatments

Posts.Content: hey Annie, I talked about a Rope to hold on to in another feed. PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE hold onto that rope just now!!!! We will all pull and push, every minute of every day!!  You WILL get through this! Just a day at a time. And every bit that you look back on which has been shite - well, that's all the bits that are already behind you!!!! Congratulate yourself for having come this far already!!! Look for the positive in all the negative - what do you see? Even just the smallest part! And then hold onto that part - that's the bit of your rope you can really hold onto! I wish I could come and see you, too, but then, by the sounds of it, your house would get quite crowded!!  Big hugs Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Don't think I can do another round :(

Posts.Content: Hey Sascha Rose, glad to hear you have your appointment. But each appointment also throws open the inevitable questions, doesn't it?!  It is such a shame that you feel so alone and so exposed at the same time. Maybe there is a friend you could take with you. I know you don't feel you want others to know. But maybe just one other person you can trust to keep your secret?  Please be assured I and others here are with you all the way, wherever you have to go - and I promise I won't peek!  Take care, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Deja vu ????

Posts.Content: Hey Bluegem, If an electric blanket is what it takes then go for it!  I agree with Kate: I have been calling our ordeal bootcamp! And the 'tanning' you just finished afterwards is no picnic either. You have put yourself through the paces both physically and emotionally, and your body is coming to the end of it's reserves just now.  Congratulations for doing so well! So glad to hear your toasted area is calming down as well.  Yes, you are bound to feel knackered! You are scarred and bruised! And now, I think you can start to feel sorry for yourself. Whilst we battle, I think we keep quite focussed. But then comes a time, when we need to let go as well. The time after the storm.  It will get better again. It will take time. But don't rush. If cosy rest is what your body is asking for, then I would listen to that battered body!  But I would also try and make use of the nice weather we appear to be blessed with just now (sitting up in Scotland myself!) Get yourself your Vit D! Lots of sunshine and a bit of fresh air.  Maybe just sitting out in the sun for a while, or a 5 minute round the block.  I think the answer to recovery from Bootcamp and tanning is Baby-steps! Nice and slow, listening to your body! It knows what it needs.  Be so proud of yourself, and don't be too frustrated with yourself! I am sure you will be getting there!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Feeling so tired and unwell

Posts.Content: probably can't help you, as I only had a lumpectomy - and it was back in October, and I cannot remember. Was glad at that time to have either my husband or my friend with me for those meetings, as my head was just all over the place.  It's a time for you to ask questions though. Anything you still aren't sure about. Probably also for your surgeon to let you know what to expect immediately after your op, like drains etc, and physio.  Was really just wanting to wish you good luck with it all! See you on the other side!   Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Pre-Op Assessment

Posts.Content: Hi everyone,  Can I reassure you that your veins will eventually recover again. more or less anyway!  I have had my last FEC now over a year ago. My right arm took the brunt of the chemo drugs, and I came to hate the red stuff going in! Absolutely hate it! Yes, the veins tighten up. So, as much as possible I worked against the tightening. Stretching, putting heat on it (Obviously not scolding the skin!). I don't know if any of it helped.  But, now I must admit, I cannot see the thick obvious lines any more which showed the thickened veins. And I can fully extend my arm again.  I am actually now very very carefully starting to use some weights (and I am only talking the minims weight of 5 kg) to get some upper body strength back into my arms! I do believe we lose a lot of muscle whilst all this treatment is going on. But you need to give yourself time!!! Slowly does it!  Hope that helps, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: FEC and sore veins

Posts.Content: hmmmm, sounds like a nerve is affected in one way or another. You are concerned, so: yeah, have it checked out.  You can call the lovely ladies at your GP surgery maybe and tell them you are a cancer patient! Then they make the appointment more urgent! Defo go and find out for yourself. You will sleep better when you know what it is.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: pain running down inside of arm

Posts.Content: I am apparently all positive (yes, it's in my cheerful nature ;)), and so after having completed my chemo I have now started Tamoxifen this week, and I am getting my first Herceptin infusion next week. So, both at the same time. As far was I understand they are both slightly different from one another. So trying to tackle the same problem from different angles, if you like. And as they are not interfering with one another, they can join forces.  The MacMillan info on both is very useful, I feel.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Herceptin AND Tamoxifen at the same time?

Posts.Content: Hey, I have had my FEC reduced twice. Eventually I ended up having cycle 5 and 6 as just EC! I also 'over-reacted' ended up with a white cell count being more or less eradicated.  As I see it: they are making the dose up by height and weight, not considering your own body functions. I have always been on the edge of being anaemic. Probably means my bone marrow doesn't tend to go into hyperactivity at best of times.  So, if you get all these side effects, I think it means that your bone marrow may be struggling, too. And if the dose is not reduced then you are potentially causing yourself more harm! Harm, which you don't need. Not in the short term and not in the long run.  It is a fine balance the oncologist is treading with your body: bringing it to the edge, but not overstepping it: he wants you to carefully balance on that rope, but he is not interested in you falling off it!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Docetaxel reduced dose

Posts.Content: I agree with Kate, I would have that checked out, too. Might be that the Letrozol doesn't agree with you, so you shouldn't cause unnecessary damage. Might just be that like the Tamoxifen there are different makes on the market, and your doc might just put you on a different make.  Keep us posted. But do go have that checked.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: letrozol and bleeding

Posts.Content: hey Annie, I am so glad you are getting personal one-to-one support from your Mac nurse now!!! Sounds good, too, that you have got some anti depressants sooooon.  You are having to deal with such a mountain right now, take every little crutch along on the way!   Never mind sounding morbid, that's how you feel just now, and with very good reason. It is such a scary time for you.  As for the lump not shrinking - it's only the first dose though you have had. And you don't know what it may have done to the other lumps. So much guess work involved. - Including your own perception of it maybe.  I remember thinking I am feeling my lump grow every minute of every day. When in fact the surgeon said to me it had already been there about 3 months.  Big massive hug, from a very wet and miserable Scotland. Keep fighting that shit! I think your body is doing exactly that - so there is nothing spare in the canister.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: bone scan today and yet another whinge from me.....a warning then...

Posts.Content: Yay, well done Anne-Marie! nearly at the finish line!  Maybe the leg hairs will go with the last one! hahaha. My eye-brows lasted until the last one and then they said good-bye. But all back 6 months on! Unfortunately even the 'lady garden'! No Brazilian any more.  All the best to everyone starting or still going through bootcamp! Go give it your all - hair an' all!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Outrageous!

Posts.Content: hey Stumble, oh dear. I am reading all your very sensible explanations as to why you shouldn't feel the way you do. REWIND! This may be all routine to your doctors, but this is sooo not routine for you! And in general we do not flaunt ourselves in front of just anyone and get a kick out of it. And if we did, then it would be our choosing. We'd be in control. And we would have some alterior motive in mind ...  Your body has been violated as you quite rightly say, but so has your soul. Your whole equilibrium has been thrown out of balance when you have had to have your breasts taken off. And like hair, and figure, and BMI, these bodily parts give us reassurance as to who we are and who we want to be. We exude confidence when we feel happy and safe in our body. Some people even hide behind their body! I am so sorry you feel yourself dirty. Sounds to me you feel ashamed of yourself? And your self esteem has been taken down a few notches in the running, no doubt. Your op is still so very recent, and you are probably still trying to come to terms with it yourself. Bandages haven't come off until recently and before you know yourself, some stranger is looking at you, and worse touching.  You haven't had time to be introduced to your new you. And you are probably grieving the loss of the old you. And everything that penetrates into your inner sanctity of your new you hits you dead on and makes you see what you have lost. And you feel you have lost your armour! It makes you feel vulnerable and exposed.  Surely with time you will get to know your new you, and you will be building your confidence again. Slowly, in time.  But, in the meantime, there are options! I think it would be a really good idea to confide in your BCnurse with this problem. And don't you worry that you are not as important as other people around you! Your nurse can maybe talk to you about seeing a counsellor, but she certain;y should also be able to talk with your consultant about whether at your next consultation you can be seen by a lady doctor.  And then there are relaxation options, such as yoga, where you get to feel your own body again. Get to know yourself again.  And definitely share this with your partner. You will find it so much easier to deal with this with him, rather than on your own. He sounds to me like he is a very perceptive guy!  But don't feel embarrassed or ashamed! This is natural! Hell, I struggled losing my hair! And a chip out of my breast!  I hope I haven't made things worse here, but I am glad you have come to share!  How does the advert go - because YOU ARE WORTH IT!  Hang on in there, it does get better. And if the guy at least is good looking, then do some window shopping instead! lol Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: I feel...violated?

Posts.Content: Sounds to me, Kimberley, that you are so frightened to loose your daughter, after all the other losses in your life, that you feel you would do anything to cling on to her.  There also sounds an unbalanced kind of gratitude from you for having your daughter in your life. And it is as if you can't quite believe that you are lucky enough to still have her. - And then she throws the duck out with the bathwater, and she makes you feel vulnerable in your desire to be mum. In being mum!  That's why I was saying earlier: let go! by letting her go, you are much more able to keep her! Let go of your fears that this was all your fault. And let go of the idea that if you don't step up to her plate she will drop you! Or even worse, you would loose her!  Your daughter is a very lucky person to have you in her life!!! She is probably also scared, and overawed. But the best way of defence is outright attack! And the closest people to us are the ones we most likely attack!  Do you find you can go for coffee with your daughter and really have a heart to heart with her? have a girly time, and in that make her aware how important she is to you. Otherwise, yes, leave her hanging dry might just sober her up a little and stop her from taking you for granted!  As for your partner, my thoughts are, he is not only not her father, so there are issues there. BUT, he also is YOUR PARTNER! and he loves you! He loves you despite the all the mess, and family you come with. But, his priority of caring would be YOU!  He sounds to me like he is letting your daughter and her partner get away with much, because it appears to make you happy! But in the instance now, it no longer makes you happy, and so he steps in from the point of view of loving and caring for you!  Yes, a counsellor sounds like a good idea, but I think really talking to your partner, appreciating maybe that his caring is for you, might help the two of you master your side of the story! Your daughter has to manage her own!  Hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: URGENTLY NEED HELP......ANOTHER ANGLE OPINION...PLEASE

Posts.Content: Hi Deb,  It's 'Arts and Crafts' day! lol. I felt reminded of Blue Peter!  A load of measurements were taken. They had all sorts of rulers and measuring discs, and then I got drawn on with black felt pen (which does wash off!). They also put sticky tape down ... AS I say: Blue Peter, take note!  Yes, tattoo: but none of your choice, just a couple of tiny dots. They feel like a needle prick when they are being done, one on the sternum for me, and one on the side. Neither are disfiguring. In fact, they had to re-do one of them for me, as it was sort of lost in amongst all my other freckles and moles! hahahaha.  It is all designed to target the correct area, without causing undue harm to surrounding areas: My left breast was 'tanned', so they made sure NOT to get the nipple on the boosters, and not to frazzle too much of my heart, either.  The whole experience is not painful. I remember my onc asked me if I had questions, and then I also had to sign a consent form, that I was not pregnant!!! Oh dear, That would just have given me the rest, I think. lol  You'll be absolutely fine. Just go with plenty of time, as they may be doing quite a bit of 'Arts and Crafts' on you! ;)   Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy planning

Posts.Content: Hey Anne, I imagine your answer will come with your own experience. I do believe that there are people who have sailed through bootcamp. Personally, I was very fortunate that I didn't work at the time, and I didn't have to.  Within each cycle of bootcamp you are most likely to get a 'week 3'. That's the week when your bloods come back up to normal, and you feel you are rid of all the poison in your body.  My worry for you as a head teacher would be: infections! Your lovely little darlings are going to bring all sorts of bugs every single day of the week. So, on days of low immunity, that might cause some worries.  My second worry would be: chemobrain. A VERY medical term for basically closing shop upstairs once you have had the chemo. In the short run I would imagine that thought processes and decision making might be lagging a little.  However, you might just be one of those people who is able to cope with your side effects.  In the ideal world you might be able to go part time. Go in when you feel fine, and have duvet days when you don't. 4 months do sound a very long time right now. But actually, it is not, and you are going to be very busy getting yourself through bootcamp. If you can take the time off, I would do it! Give yourself time really look after yourself. And take work home for the days you are able.  Good luck.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Back to work?

Posts.Content: Hey Charly, It is not just your wife who is going through this - it's BOTH of you. And if you feel your wife is different, or you feel that you are not happy with what's going on, then you are in the very best position to be challenging the situation.  Sometimes the worst person to ask is the one who is directly treated, because they may not even realise changes themselves!  I think by the time that you are married/live together for centuries, you stop being two individuals, and you become one entity with two bodies! And just as much as you would know when your right arm hurts, or twitches, you know when things are 'not quite right' with your OH.  It may just be that you both need reassurance by the medics. But you certainly don't have to just put up with what's given and decided! You guys need to function! And if you don't then the medication as prescribes is not right for you! And changes need to be considered!  I would ask your lovely wife, whether she would mind, if you both make an appointment together at your doctor's. And if she agrees then I would have a chat with her, before you go, and explain, why you think you'd like for her to be checked over, so she is not caught off-guard in front of the doctor.  But once you are both there, then you both have chance to ask the questions, and you both have each other to chat about the conversation, and what that means for you both.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Aromasin - Personality change

Posts.Content: hahahahaha, mistymoley! we must have posted just about the same time! And very much on the same wave length!  Happy Christmas. Dxx
Posts.Title: URGENTLY NEED HELP......ANOTHER ANGLE OPINION...PLEASE

Posts.Content: hey, I took my Tamoxifen with me on my travels. Just kept to the same 24 hours though of taking them. So with time change, you have to work out your 'new 'time whilst you are away.  have a fantastic time! Don't get sunburnt!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Long haul travel on Tamoxifen

Posts.Content: Hey Kimberley, Deep breath -  Loving your daughter and grandchildren doesn't mean being a doormat! And Love is not something you can 'buy'.  You are right to have stepped away. As much as it hurts you, and it hurts your daughter, the couple of them need to sort themselves out! Bank of mum and dad at their age isn't a long term solution. And it seems that you are close to having communication problems with your partner because of their issues.  I imagine you feel guilty, possibly thinking you have something to do with where your daughter has got to. But, realistically, the choices she now makes as an adult are HER choices. And you need to learn to LET GO! Love and care, yes, but not be responsible!  They became reliant on you as well, and so the choices they made to cope were not coping strategies to overcome the deep problems, they were coping strategies for the short term.  I feel for you, as you are torn, because you feel your daughter is resenting you. And she may well throw a paddy, but then that's not an adult adult relationship! And that makes me wonder whether there is a possibility that your daughter also has huge problems coping in this situation.  There is a first stop SHE should take probably at the Citizen Advice Bureau. They would be able to advise her financially and socially. But, she has to mean to make changes for herself!  This is absolutely not your responsibility! They are grown ups!!  And yeah, Tamoxifen sucks! And when we are tired we are much less in a position to fight the fights! It's easier to just give in, isn't it. For peace and quiet! But, you know yourself, in the long-run this way just keeps biting you in the bum, over and over again!  Big hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: URGENTLY NEED HELP......ANOTHER ANGLE OPINION...PLEASE

Posts.Content: yikes! I had a very sore mouth and throat with my first chemo! It never got as bad on the following ones though!  I didn't like the idea of the mouthwashes which stain teeth. And I was lucky to have an in-depth chat with the resident hospital pharmacist!  Basically we agreed that good old salt water gargle would do the trick just as well as any mouthwashes. Dissolve a bit of table salt in luke warm water, and gargle with that. Swirl it around your mouth. Do this maybe twice a day. BUT DON"T SWALLOW!!  Good luck.  Also, you may find that anything you eat kind of burns on your sore gums. I found chicken good to swallow. But be careful of any sauce, because they usually contain something acidic, and then you are back to square one.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: sore mouth and throat

Posts.Content: Hi, tbh, I am not sure where exactly it is you are wanting to go. Is it a day's drive away? Further?  Week 3 will be your best week! So, if you are planning to go anywhere, then a week 3 is the best one to aim for.  Personally, I was utterly grateful that my husband bundled me up on a week 3 weekend, and he drove me somewhere pretty, not too far, with a nice B&B waiting for me.  It is true, you are not likely able to entertain the large family. And you may just want to spend time quietly. However, I change of wallpaper, watching the grandkids play, there is a lot to be said for that.  I am wondering whether you may have the option of letting your kids and grandkids go on this holiday, and you join them if you feel fit enough to do so. Go just for a couple of days, see how you get on.  Problem with planning anything during chemo time is the fact that your bloods might not play game. And then your anticipated weeks get swallowed up because it is taking your body longer to recover! Might not happen, but you'd be better off preparing yourself to be flexible with your activities.  I really do like the idea of getting out when you can. It does your soul a world of good. Just be careful, and pace yourself a little.Remember, once you are out the other side of bootcamp you can enjoy your holidays again much more easily.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Holidays during chemo.

Posts.Content: Fantastic! Well done! Getting there!  Same again next time round then!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: FEC - unco-operative veins!!!....and advice on PICC line

Posts.Content: Oh Daisydot, that is just shit!  If it's not one thing it's another ... Still keeping fingers crossed it's not gone anywhere else.  And then it's back down to business. You have done it all before, you can do it again, and we'll be right here with you.  Huge hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Second time around? Results tomorrow

Posts.Content: The most attempts they had on me on one occasion was 9! That was 3 attempts at home, then 3 more in hospital and the last 3 were tried by an anaesthetist! My veins didn't like FEC either. And Herceptin became somewhat a challenge.  As my lymph nodes had not been affected, and I only had a few of them removed, I let them have a go on my lymph arm as well. To swap sides from the chemo arm.  However, the best advice I got was to immerse my hands in warm water in the sink for a few minutes, just before the nurse had a poke with her needle. It worked a treat. Made the veins come out to play. Another idea is to wear gloves before you get there.  We ended up using child size needles as well.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: FEC - unco-operative veins!!!....and advice on PICC line

Posts.Content: Hey janey, Can't say I waited that long. My hair started coming out after two weeks. But I didn't use a cold cap. I was gonna go all or nothing.  I found the morning when loads of hair was on my pillowcase really traumatic, and so I got my son to shave it off. By the looks of it, it would have come out much more radically around the sides, as opposed to the top of the head - really the other way round to the way men lose their hair. So that wouldn't have looked cool.  My greatest worry in retrospect was, that I was so scared that I wouldn't recognise myself after - and that's just not the case. I am relieved to say, it's still me! But I don't have the trauma of watching it go every day and worrying myself. I picked out hair from my head like picking flowers in the garden. It wasn't nice.  And I am really enjoying the head scarves, messing around, and finding a little bit of a new side to me.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Hair falling out!

Posts.Content: hey loujay, Oh dear, that's not cool! I have now been on Tamoxifen for the last 2 years. And so far so good.  I hear what you are saying about Tamoxifen side effects. Have you recently changed the make? Could that have affected things?  otherwise I am also wondering whether this may have nothing to do with the Tamoxifen as such, but rather that your body is coping with hormone changes. Those can cause hair loss as well.  I would go to your GP and have a chat. See whether they can adjust your meds, or check out what your body is doing right now.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen and Hair Loss

Posts.Content: Hey Rebecca, I think this is one of those things, where there is no right or wrong. And changing your mind over and over just adds spice to the dullness of our lives just now! lol  I have gone for no cold cap. I enjoy seeing my short crop in the mirror, knowing it most probably won't last much longer... but curiously, I am also looking forward to using my lovely very expensive new scarves, which I bought just before first chemo session.  I shower and wash hair as normal, and just go with the flow on that one. I KNOW I will get upset when the day comes and it all falls out! I have been to see my hairdresser, and she assured me I only need to give her a call and she can go shave it all off. I don't fancy the trauma of prolonged losing.  My motto is, feel inside of me: how do I best cope, what is important. And if I change my mind, then that's part of the course, too. Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: If the cap fits...

Posts.Content: Thinking of you today.  remember, you have done it before - you can do it again!!! (If needs be!)  Hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Second time around? Results tomorrow

Posts.Content: Hey Annie, Thinking of you today.  I imagine, as I said before I think, the problem with Chemo is, it also stops good cells from growing. So, if it causes havoc in the lungs, its like felling the old trees, without being able to plant the new ones just yet, and all you are left with is fallen wood on the ground. And walking through that mess is REALLY hard - and you get splinters, too!  So you are going in to get a clear-up operation going! Nothing wrong with that! - just 'bad timing' as ever with this fight!  Lots of love Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Going to ward tomorrow

Posts.Content: hey Trudi, Good advice from the lovely ladies!  I would like to add another angle. One that I keep making comparison with: pregnancy and childbirth. Please bare with me!  When we give birth, initially we are very good at getting up through the night. Part of the reason is: adrenaline! the newness of it all makes us sit up and we are extra vigilant.  And then, as routine sets in, suddenly your kid starts teething. And then it gets really difficult. Who has the energy still to keep getting up through the night? Is it his turn or yours? ...  You see, I think we have a similar set-up here during Bootcamp and Tanning! In the beginning we cope. And then slowly but surely we get drained of the usual energy, never mind the extra bit of adrenaline! We just run on empty! And that is exactly where you are finding yourself right now.  You have managed to keep going so far, and undoubtedly you will find the extra push to make it all the way. But now there is nothing spare in the tank. And as you are sat on empty with the little yellow light flashing on the dashboard, you have doubts, not only whether you make it all the way, but whether maybe you are not as safe as you were hoping and trusting yourself to be!  Your trust in yourself and in your body has taken a big dip. And now that you are nearing the end of treatment the thought is starting to creep in that you are now left to your own devices on this again. Funnily enough, within the routine of Bootcamp and Tanning, we start feeling safe! We are proactive in fighting back. And you are starting to see the end of that now. Which gives you a sense of insecurity.  So, put the insecurity feeling and the lack of energy together, and you are just struggling. But people like your sister don't see your inner self, they see what they like to see, especially when you put on your make-up and try and cope!  From here on in I would prioritise! You know you are limited with your energy, so do what you feel you want to do, what you can cope with. In your time and your space! You do not have to justify yourself to anyone but yourself!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: help feel awful at 2 radiotherapy to go

Posts.Content: hi, Who do you feel you have to be brave for? Are you sure the people around you wouldn't cope, if you had a good howl?!  I do very much believe in riding the storm. I have cried and cried at Heathrow airport the day after my diagnosis, as we were off on a planned holiday. I am very fortunate that I have a wonderful husband, who just took it all. And then, when I had cried enough, I found space for strength again. To start focussing on what was coming up.  Well done for having taken the first hurdle already. Now, just take it one step at a time. All this stuff is very draining, and I don't think we feel very much in control during chemo. I call it bootcamp - there is a taskmaster in charge and he puts you through your paces from now on. But remember: fight the cancer, not the chemo.  Don't go google, because you can get yourself seriously frightened. But have a look at the info provided here by MacMillan. And maybe give the nurses a call here. They are very well qualified to give you some more info on your triple neg diagnosis.  There are a lot of folk here who are doing what you are doing just now. And there are people like myself, who have finished the bootcamp and the 'tanning'. And I think we are all good adverts for the fighting spirit in us and the determination that this little shit is not going to get us!  Hugs from afar, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: New to all this

Posts.Content: Tiredness comes with the job description of what we are doing/have been doing! Like Kate says, best to acknowledge it, and give in to it. "Because you are worth it'! lol Seriously, though, your body and mind have been tormented, and you have been zapped off every ounce of energy left in your body.  You use energy to heal!!! remember, your treatment has broken down parts of your body in order to get rid of nasty c-cells. Now you are needing time to mend! And the mending process is going to consume any energy you still are able to provide.  I imagine you will feel quite vulnerable as well just now. We don't have much of a thick skin left at the end. So, be aware and don't worry. It is totally natural. We'd like to be super-human, but we do face the fact that we appear to come to our limits after all.  So, rest is good. But so is fresh air and going for walks. You might find that resting during the day makes it more difficult to sleep through the night. That's where I would go for walks, do a bit of exercise to make the body physically tired. It's a different kind of tiredness to the lethargy I think we come to feel. Just slowly reintroduce your body and your mind to little challenges, which are achievable and which will make you feel good about what you have done.  Problem I came to at the end of bootcamp and tanning was a feeling of 'no future', no planning, no direction. And that seemed to zap energy as well. I found myself little achievable goals, which were not pushing me to any limits but gave me the start of a feeling of direction, progress, hope and future again.  Lol, this is getting seriously deep here ...  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy.

Posts.Content: Hey Marg,  realistically, you haven't got a leg to stand on there for the year!  I found that very frustrating too. But looking back, the garden survived. And I had great fun with my 'kids', mostly bribing them to even throw the mower about. My daughter and her boyfriend got really stuck in, when they were about. But as they are students, living in Glasgow, that really wasn't anything much more than occasional weekends.  My sister-in-law came to make a difference and I ended up taking her to casualty with a grass blade cut on her hand!  My suggestion is, find a little army of helpers, kids like to earn pocket money, and older blokes like to show they can 'bench'! So, if you are feeling well, then make it an event, get the BBQ out.  And then go buy a really lovely garden bench, in anticipation of a much much nicer summer than we are getting a winter just now.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: op

Posts.Content: Hey Louise,  I am so sorry. And I can't help with your questions. But, I can send great big bear hugs!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: INFLAMMATORY BREAST CANCER NEW REDNESS

Posts.Content: Hi Louise,  Isn't it just so bizarre, we hate the darned things, until they have gone, and then we celebrate them back! Because it's a connection to who we were before.  I have NO idea why and whether this is normal - what's normal?! I would note it down in a diary though, and also whether you feels it's heavy, and how long it does bleed. Then you have much more of a reference to talk with your doctor. And if you get to have them more regular, then you have a longer term diary on it.  Hope it's not a sore one! :)  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: periods!

Posts.Content: hey there,  yeah, it's shit! No two ways!  A diary is a very good idea, because as you go through the next cycles of 'bootcamp' you can make comparisons, makes it easier and is sort of reassuring.  Problem with chemo side effects is, everyone gets them, but until YOU get them yourself, it's difficult to explain what it feels like. Just like being steamrollered!  Really important to drink plenty, they say at least 2 litres, to flush the stuff back out of your system. And when it come to food, I would go with what you feel like. Your body will tell you exactly what it needs and what it won't cope with.  As to feeling guilty - well - dumb of me to say 'don't'. I think it's possibly your fear and your frustration hitting you. And again, the chemo poison breaks down your defences, both physically and mentally. It does so for all the right reasons, but it makes you more susceptible to feeling weak.  Maybe, taking your daughter's love and embracing her unconditional need and love for you, may just help you. There is a lot of positive energy that flows from your relationship with her. Take it, it will do you good.  And dragging yourself out fir little walks, even if it's just 5 minutes round the block, I think fills your lungs with fresh air, and gives you a feel-good factor.  And as for the washing machine ... you gotta laugh! Scream first, then laugh - it never rains, but it pours!  and then get people to rally around you to get your washing done next door.  Just think: ONE down!!!! It's a good start!  And, maybe make a call to your BC nurse, and check out whether all your pains are within normal limits. No point suffering needlessly. It may reassure you too.  Big hug,  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: 1st fec

Posts.Content: yay on having a bath!! get the bubbly out, and the candles!  As for the tanning - yes, don't wait about! if the onc is unhappy with the wait then you go for it, and call these people up for an earlier start!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Feeling drained!

Posts.Content: Hey Sally,  welcome to this exclusive club. And yeah, the beginning of this is soooo unsettling, so confusing and so scary. But there are loads of us here, who have got past the beginning, and who are still here, and are sharing so inspirationally how they have been coping, or not coping.  The treatment for BC is incredibly good these days. So from a physical point of view, i think you are in the most capable hands. Yes, it's tough, but there is medication to stem sickness etc. What you are going to struggle with more probably is that you are entering, as you already realise, an emotional roller coaster. And getting emotional support out there is really tough. I think this is why this group here is so very inspirational. You can draw from others' experiences. Peer support.  As for work. That's shit coincidence indeed. But, unless you are absolutely dependent on your income, maybe it is possible to look at it from another viewpoint. It gives you time to focus on yourself, and your immediate needs for your own well-being.  The whirl is going to settle, once you are on the road of treatment. It's the waiting beforehand that is going to torment you and test your patience. but it is very important to give the team all the time to get your diagnosis right.  hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with breast cancer, made redundant 2 weeks ago and...

Posts.Content: Hey, we also do insurance with our bank. We called them, had a very lovely chat with the guy. Found he was very sensitive in his questions. And we are covered now.  I would absolutely speak to your guys at the bank for insurance cover. Just in case ....  Good luck. Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: dilemma, to declare or not?

Posts.Content: Hey,  I understand the pain can become excruciating. And analgesics won't touch that level of pain then.  I am wondering, is it not possible to crush the little blighters? And then remove those via keyhole surgery?  The problem with chemo is that it destroys all new cells. Good or bad, it doesn't care to choose. So healing would be very slow progress, even with keyhole.  You really are in a predicament with this just now. I am so sorry.  Have you had a chat with your oncologist about the potential damage caused by giving the chemo a break? Is it as bad as you fear? Or are you imagining worse than it may turn out to be?  You certainly need some reassurance and some support by the medical team who are caring for you.  Hope you get sorted quickly.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: gallbladder op whilst undergoing oral chemo

Posts.Content: hey Maggie, I feel for you. Unfortunately, it sounds like your ribs got a bit of a 'spare rib' treatment, and they got a little frazzled. Also unfortunately, even though you have finished your tanning (well done for that!), the actual radiation is going to carry on for I think a couple of weeks. - Bit like a microwave, you are meant to me leaving your food  to stand a little longer, because it is still doing it's stuff.  Part of your discomfort may just be that you are unsure about your pain, and about progress. So, if your doctor can reassure you, that all is well, then maybe you are able to relax a little into your new situation.  Apart from that though, I don't believe that suffering with pain quietly is an option. So, I would find out, what pain killers you are able to take.  And then I imagine it is a 'be patient and wait' game again. I am sure it will get better, as the rib cage can start to recover from the recent onslaught. - Wouldn't think it will go fully, as my rib cage does feel different still, and I finished tanning on Boxing Day of last year.  Good luck - and if nothing helps, resort to wine and chocolates! That works!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: rib pains

Posts.Content: Hang on in there!!!! Choccies is a good start! And the wine is something to look forward to.  I cannot imagine your lovely husband getting fed-up with you! You have every right to be a moaning minnie! I would be too!  Glad you are getting in touch with the nurses, there must be something they can give you, or at least reassure you!  I am wondering if ice-packs might work. Not directly on the skin, but wrapped into a towel. Also, someone suggested putting the aqueous cream into the fridge, so it is nice and cold when applying to your blistered skin.  I am aslo wondering about ticking off a calendar, day by day. Maybe write a little diary of everyday, and what I am hoping is, is that you might just see tiny baby steps of improvement, to give you courage to hold on.  Lots of love Dorothee xx PS: your OH might progress to using the hoover, oh, and the duster??? - can I hire him???
Posts.Title: rib pains

Posts.Content: Still waiting to hear from my chemo nurse, who is coming to start my first chemo cycle tomorrow.  Lucky me is having my chemo at home. BUT, she hasn'tt been in touch, AT ALL! And I don't know whether she is even bothering to call me today. So, instead of enjoying my last day of freedom, and beautiful sunshine, I am hovering around the phone.  Really getting nervous anyway, and feeling that my mother's pussy-footing is annoying me too today. - She doesn't want to do anything wrong, so she keeps apologising for everything and anything, and leaves even suggestions of what I might want to eat the next few days up to me! I don't know and I don't care what I want to eat then, but I am wanting her to take charge of that, so I don't HAVE to care. Thought that's what she was here for ...  I am just in my own way today ....  Thanks for listening!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: aaarrgh - day before ...

Posts.Content: Hi Jacquie,  Oh dear, bootcamp is really knocking you about! But, you are half way!  I am not entirely sure whether your struggles are with the physical chemo drugs and body reactions, or whether you feel you cannot cope with it mentally any longer.  I reckon the discussions with your team will be looking at either or the other category, or a bit of both.  Medically, your Tax is going to give you a different experience, I imagine, to the FEC you have just gone through.  Emotionally though, you may not distinguish the two different ingredients of your cocktail, and you just feel burnt out. - And in that case, you may find it helpful to tackle your support system around you! Can you afford not to work just now? Can you afford to go and find complementary therapies, yoga, time-out, just to pace your self.  There are counsellors you can talk to, and drop-in centres where you can go and just get a change of scenery, and a friendly face you can make you a cuppa!  If your discussion is about what happens now, if you decide you cannot cope with another chemo, then for starters, you have done 3! That's pretty cool! 3 is already 3 more than none!  I guess your next considerations may include whether you can take Herceptin? What hormone tablets may be suitable? And what other options you may have.  Don't be too hard on yourself, though! this bootcamp business is tough! It throws you physically and emotionally in equal measures. Only, your onc has a big bag full of goodies for all your physical ailments, but there is nothing much in there for your emotional well-being! And that just needs to be readdressed!  Hugs,  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Not tolerating chemo

Posts.Content: That's why we are here, Jacquie. Glad you are feeling a little brighter. And so glad you felt your pouring out has helped you.  As to massage: when I went to my local beauty salon, I was told they wouldn't touch me for at least 5 years! I had been totally unprepared for this rejection, felt embarrassed to have even asked, and left with my tail between my legs. And then I asked my oncologist, who pointed me in the direction of my local cancer support centre. There are therapists, who are specially trained, as you don't want to upset your sylph system, and areas of operations. So these people are marvellous at treating you and making you feel relaxed and tonnes better. Often they are also really good at listening, so when you feel you need to pour your heart out a little more in the moment then they can catch you.  If you have something like a Maggies then that may be a good place to go and ask. But your chemo nurse or BCnurse should also be able to point you in the right direction. Makes all the difference, when you are feeling shite! - Just don't try going to your local salon, you might get the same 'treatment' I did! lol  And now for a nice glass of wine! And roll yourself up on the sofa.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Not tolerating chemo

Posts.Content: Hey TimTam, Your body never recovers to where it's been before the previous FEC. And so as you are getting toward the final ones you are experiencing the accumulation of FEC.  I had 6 FEC, well, actually, I ended up just with EC.My body wan't coping well in the end either, so they reduced to dosages.  Side effects I had were certainly not just the lethargy and inability to tolerate certain foods. But I also became quite light sensitive, so I would be donning my shades for the days after chemo. And my tear ducts dried out so my eyes kind of got sore.  As your bloods are being checked all the way along, you know you are being looked after as best they can. But, you know you have your thermometer beside your bed, and if you should feel lousy, then don't wait about, but contact whoever needs to know so they can kickstart your antibiotics.  Only 2 more to go though!!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Not tolerating chemo

Posts.Content: thanks everyone! Feeling much better. I did lock myself in my room for an hour! That was exactly what I needed. And afterwards I thought, sod the nurse, she leave me a message. So I went out and did my last bit of shopping. When I got back home I found she had spoken onto the machine, left her number, and I was able to call her back. - She does sound lovely! So, all good again - for now ... Long may it last!  Nice dinner tonight! Beef Olives. Might as well enjoy them whilst I can!  Thanks for the support yet again. Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: aaarrgh - day before ...

Posts.Content: Congrats Alison on being finally rewarded the 'tanning't-shirt'! - Tank top??? ;)  great to hear you have got there. Me thinks it's time for some bubbly!  Hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Feeling bewildered

Posts.Content: Hey Jacquie,  Klick on this link for the Maggie's Centres. Hope there is one near you, too!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Not tolerating chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Mollydog,  I would have that checked out. You can call your GP in the morning and see if you can get slot, as a panicked cancer patient!  It may be nothing, other than having something like a stiff neck, because you have been lying awkwardly during the tanning sessions, or because you are sleeping funny as you are subconsciously protecting your upper body during sleep.  But it's nearly Christmas, and you may very well be anxious right over Christmas if you don't have it checked out.  We do tend to get paranoid quite easily, but that doesn't mean to say there isn't anything wrong. And the more you worry the more you anticipate the discomfort.  So I would absolutely get it seen tomorrow.  Hugs in the meantime,  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: radiotherapy after effects

Posts.Content: Interesting - not too sure. But in my case they originally took a biopsy first and sent that off, and then took my lump out and had that tested too.  The results have come back in drips and drabs. My op was mid May, and my most recent result came last week, when they I was told I was Her2 pos.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Genetic Test tomorrow

Posts.Content: Hey, I started taking tamoxifen early December. So far so good. Yes, I get the hot flushes too, but I can cope with those. I don't feel I am needing as much sleep as I used to either.  I take mine in the morning, after I got up. Seems to be a good routine! You don't need to take it with food, I checked with my onc, so I just take it when I put the kettle on for my first cup of tea. - I think, whatever time suits you best, but make it a routine, so you are less likely to forget when 'the novelty runs out'.  I think as far as other side effects, because you are going to experience hormone changes, it might me useful to look at your diet in general. Just making sure you get your calcium, vitamins and minerals.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: tamoxifen advice

Posts.Content: Hey Sascha Rose, Grieving is a process which, you may very well know, has different stages.  You are obviously in a very resentful stage just now. You have probably already been through the 'why me' stage.  Have you researched further into grieving stages? It might be helpful in order to break down your thought processes. If you can see how you have already progressed through some of your grieving stages, then you can actually see 'progress' when it looks like one never ending nightmare.  It can also show you that, as you have progressed already, there is no reason why you should stop progressing - and at the end of the grieving tunnel, there is light. It is there for you too.  '2 years on average' is pretty meaningless. Who is average? How long is a piece of string? It will take its time, but I wouldn't sit around waiting for 2 years to elapse. I would wait for longer, warmer days to pick up from winter blues.  hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Two years....!

Posts.Content: Hey guys, good luck with your chemo-bootcamps!  Yes, sometimes we get a delay, because of infections or because the blood-count is wrong. But, it only feels like an insurmountable wait just now. In the big picture, having to delay a week doesn't make any difference.
