Just prolongs the anticipation of this unknown entity called chemo! - Everyone says it's rough, but until you get started you don't actually know what rough means for you specifically.  On a note of Olbas and equivalents: Please, once you have started chemo, be very very careful using those meds!  You will find that the hairs inside your nose also go elsewhere to play, which leaves the lining of your nose for months on end like a silky baby's bottom! You will notice it run more easily, and probably bleed more readily. All this will recover once chemo is done. BUT, whilst it is so delicate, don't use harsh things like Olbas! It burns like crap!!!! Take my word for it!  Good luck on your way through bootcamp!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: need advice

Posts.Content: I agree with Mistymoley: have it checked out. Then you know.  Our problem is, we immediately conclude the worst, and yet, it may be something altogether different.  On the note of: don't google - I am not so sure that I would include 'side effects for a certain drug'. You need to inform yourself, and the google engine is a good method to use. Finding specific info is invaluable to our coping strategy. But what we should be aiming for is objective facts of info, provided by a recognised forum, be that Macmillan, or the NHS or the drug company itself.  I reckon when we say 'don't google', it means stay away from subjective comments: people's experiences, people's stories, and worst of all the stories you get in the daily somethings which are provocative, hurtful, frightening, just because they sell papers.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Nipple discharge

Posts.Content: Hey, I am just finishing 2nd week after 6th chemo. With chemos 5 & 6 I even had to say goodbye to my eye brows. So, now I am eagerly waiting for the miracle of new hair growth! So excited, but I think I need to be a bit more patient!  I will let people know when I can see a difference!  With respect to wigs - I never went for wigs, I bought head scarves. Lots of different ones, to suit my moods and occasions. I found though, that wearing scarves, I would knot them up at the base of my neck, and I could feel that knot, and I would therefore restrict my head movements at times.  I came to wearing my son's purple beanie! - I am a cool 47 year old wearing a purple snowboarder beanie!!! Yay! - But honestly: it is soooo comfy!  So, there are alternatives to sweaty wigs out there. Just got to experiment for a while. Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: when does your hair come back

Posts.Content: hey Daisyteabag, sounds to me like you are holding one hell of a feather duster there!  Well done for getting through your treatment in one piece. brilliant News.  Problem is, and I think we all have this, triple neg or positive: it is really hard to start feeling confident again about your body. I think we lost faith in the ability to help ourselves, after we have had to give up all control, because our body was invaded and was doing its own thing for a while.  It is this trust, that actually your body does know what to do, which we need to claw back for ourselves. However, it has done it! With the help of all the medical intervention.  And so there is no reason why it shouldn't keep on doing what it knows to do.  In all of this doom and gloom, you know at least that now you are on the medics' radar! If there is anything going wrong again, then they will know pretty quickly.  But for those of us who have done the treatment, and come out the other side, it is a slow and fragile walk to find your inner self again. The one that can trust in your own body, and in your own intuition.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Triple negative

Posts.Content: Good to hear you have come to a decision, which you are now 'happy' with. I am going along the same route as you. Having done 2 chemos - there is a light at the end of a very long tunnel! - The decision was made for me by by oncologist - but, like you, i would have made the same one - and I STILL would!  Calm is goooood! Get that energy bundled, deep breath. You will be fine!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Chemo - decision made

Posts.Content: Hey Deb,  congrats for having got the bugger out!  Mine was smaller, and my glands were clear,too. But, I had/have the same issue with the numbness, I think. I asked whether the surgeon had cut nerves, and I had been assured that no major nerves had been severed. Still, the feeling radiating from the axilla to the chest feels different. At first it was like after the dentist! But feeling has slowly come back, just as the blue dye is slowly receding! My op was in May.  I think in the end, even if no major nerves have been torn, we have got nerves under the axilla, and those nerves will have been compromised. They will improve, but I think this was a price to pay for getting our life back!  I have full range movement of my arm. The restrictions are more with having the 'tanning' now - radiotherapy makes the skin very delicate. But again, a price I am willing to pay for getting my life back.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: numb feeling under arm after lumpectomy

Posts.Content: I am wondering, if you find you can sleep for up to 4 hours in the day, are you sleeping on the sofa? Are you, for now, more comfortable there than in your bed?  The other thing to be aware of is the rhythm of sleep: under normal circumstances I think most of us say we sleep all night, and that gives us probably about 7 or 8 hours sleep. HOWEVER, the sleep pattern is such that we don't actually sleep our deep sleep for a whole 7 to 8 hours. And we come to wake again at about 4 hours. And that is why, when you sleep in the day, and you relax properly, you get your 4 hours.  I got myself in a right state during and after all the treatments, because I expected to just sleep through the night, as, like yourself, I was exhausted. But then I found I would wake in the early hours, and couldn't get back to sleep. So I started fighting it, which made things worse! Fact is, even if we just lie and relax, then we give our body a rest.  But you are saying you are uncomfortable in your bed, and that is not relaxing by any means. Have you go yourself all the pillows in the world, which people get for pregnancy etc? It takes a while to get comfy again, but you will get there. It's still early days, and things need to settle back down again. Make sure you take your pain relief before you go to bed. And if you can, get into a nice relaxing bubble bath before bed, too.  And these are just the physical aspects of your dilemma. There may be gremlins lurking in the dark, when you have all the time and your mind starts to analyse what has just happened in the past few months. It takes time. But you will get there.  Hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Getting better but can't sleep at night

Posts.Content: Hey Littlegem, If you feel that angry, then this is a good place to let rip! Apparently another good way is to take raw eggs into the shower. Personally, I very much believe in throwing plates and mugs!  Yeah, this is shit. And when people around you are oblivious to your pain and throw it in your face, then it makes it all that much harder to cope. And it doesn't help to shout at people, because they only get offended and don't understand.  I'd go back to throwing plates. If you have people around you, they would understand, and they can see your agony and have the chance to empathise.  I believe it is better in than out! So, please keep writing your thoughts. At the moment your worries and your upset seems to strangle you. There is not much space for hope just now, is there?! Btw, I'd go outside with the plate throwing! Concrete works well! Hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Bah humbug

Posts.Content: it seems bizarre to me that we are living in a society where we get norms of 'how to feel'. And when the majority is in a celebratory mood, then it appears to wrong to feel a different range of sentiments. And then we feel guilty about how we feel, and we feel we are a nuisance and we are not pulling ourselves together.  But, realistically, we have been given all our emotions for all the right reasons. Provided free of charge by mother nature!  The reason we feel resentful, bitter, angry etc is because basically, we are in a position where all those emotions come to light! Recognising them, and appreciating how you are feeling is at this point much more helpful than giving yourself a hard time that you are not able to dig out the expected happy face.  And with that, my advice is to share how you feel! It makes it more real for yourself! Once you start writing it all down or share verbally, then it is out there and you can start working with it. Whilst your thoughts are all muddled inside of you, they just grow, like a bottle of bubbly about to explode, when you start unscrewing the lid.  Yeah, that bubbly has been shaken - but just keeping it still now won't really do the job. You need to start pouring some, taste it, or let it run down the drain!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Bah humbug

Posts.Content: I don't think there is much of a 'tiny' elephant in our rooms any more once we have gone through all this. I think there's either no elephant - or it walks in through the front door and gets stuck in the door frame, and you get claustrophobic and can't seem to get out! I had a panic not long ago just before setting off on my hols! And it scared me all through the holidays, so much so, that I rang my BC nurse and arranged to see the oncologist as soon as I got back home.  - All was good in the end. Thank goodness.  Problem is, we used to be oblivious like everyone else, and think, quite rightly, it's just a muscle swing or a cyst etc. Now we have experienced the real deal, and everything can now be a reoccurrence! Even though, the likelihood is probably just as low as it was before we knew about the very first one.  Reassurance is everything. Waiting for results to come is one thing. But waiting to make a decision of whether to find out what it is .... As my husband once said: you know it's not nothing. So, deep breath and then go and figure it out.  The good thing is, they will take it seriously, because of your history. And I don't think there should be anyone around giving you a hard time for maybe appearing to be a hypochondriac. I think we have all earned our stripes for being professional hypochondriacs now!  I think you need to push that big elephant back out into green pastures outside. Get him out of your doorframe!  hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: new pain and worried!

Posts.Content: hey Kittycat, Well done for going to have it seen to! I am totally with you on needing to know!  What very useless advice is that anyway 'we don't offer because people don't want to know'. That may well be the case for some, but that is not an option for me either! I do need to know, just like you. And then I can move forward knowing.  Hopefully you will find that all is as it should be. And you can lay your mind to rest for another little while. Until the next ache or twinge. But, it's better to know, than the constant fear of 'not knowing'. That kind of fear stops you in your tracks. Puts you into uncertain waters - and possibly totally unnecessarily.  Let me know your results.  Big hugs,  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: new pain and worried!

Posts.Content: Hey Nicola, I have not had to have tax, and I have not experienced the itching you are describing myself. However, I can well imagine your agitation with it! And then you can't sleep and it get worse through the night and the husband, and then he falls asleep and probably infuriates you just because he is breathing ... Now, I have had those kind of nights myself!  I have ended up taking myself onto the cold leather sofa during a night, or sleep in the spare room. Just so I wouldn't wind myself up even more, and so I could give my OH a good chance to catch the sleep he really needed. It wasn't permanent, and it worked. Better than getting ratty in the night, thinking of ways to throttle him. lol As for the itching: you are doing everything I would have thought of. Try ice, try cooling your body down. Not wearing anything scratchy, just keep to cotton. But you probably already know that.  I would chat with your oncologist though about your side effects! Apart from anything else, I believe you need all your energy to be fighting your cancer cells just now, and atm it looks like you are channelling all your energy into not climbing up the walls. And you are getting sleep deprivation, and that's just fuels the whole disastrous problem!  Your chemo is meant to be helping you! It's not meant to be torturing you! See the difference? The torture is merely the side effect! And if you can work through this with more comfort but with just as much effectiveness, then you would be feeling much better in yourself!! Let your consultant in on your problems. He has your best chances of survival at his interest, and he knows how to best go about that! Don't second guess your options! Let him worry about those.  Hope you get some relief soon!  Hugs Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Docetaxel/Cyclophosamide

Posts.Content: keeping fingers crossed the antihistamine knocks you out! lol - Now, there might me a gap in the market: knocking people out for the period of bootcamp! And after 6 months sleep you will feel nice and refreshed! ;)  Well done for sharing with your GP! These guys are on your side, you know! lol  Glad I could help a little, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Docetaxel/Cyclophosamide

Posts.Content: I had my treatments throughout 2012. So, come 2013 I felt I really needed to take control again. And I gave myself the target of running the Race for Life for the first time. And so I started running.  It was then last autumn that I have started taking to the gym as I found the run outside treacherous and cold.  Bringing the upper body muscles back up to scotch is a tall order. Everything feels different, and muscles are just not there to support anything.  So, my suggestion would be, go for it, but listen to your body, go gentle, and don't have great expectations to begin with. You will get there, but it does take time, and you don't want to overdo anything and cause injury.  But, there is nothing quite like getting out there again, taking your life back into your own hands, looking for achievements and enjoying the exercise!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Joining gym after Breast cancer.

Posts.Content: Aww, Elaine, can I give you a biiiig hug right through here?! - I understand what long dark nights are like, too - and yet I have a loving husband - who sleeps through my troubled nights! lol  What I do is, I read! I switch on the light and I get out a good read! It lets the night pass a little easier, and even get me to think other thoughts.  But there is nothing like a good hug when you need one!  And, a good cry does wonders, too! Makes me feel much better after.  Dorothee x
Posts.Title: Relationships and cancer

Posts.Content: hey Karen,  I have felt a blip between chemo finish and rads start. It seems to be a period of time where we first come to a standstill after all the fighting. And we are making first self assessments... It does get easier again, or at least it did for me, when I started rads, because I felt I am fighting again. Keeping busy holding the devil at bay.  I am now done with rads as well. And I am okay at the moment. I get my moments, but I feel I have bombarded myself with all I could, and, I do trust in Herceptin!!!  So, it's a case of 're-normalising'. Learning the new normal. Learning that, yes, we have been there, but we have done it, and if anything: we are maybe at an advantage, because we are now checked over regularly, and we are aware.  I don't think I will ever go back to the carefree me from before. So, new me has to embrace what has happened and trust that the fight I have given it has been a good one.  Just also, maybe it is this time of year as well, we have been so busy with the run-up of Christmas. And now all the puff has gone out of the energy driven weeks. It's cold and dark and dull outside. That in itself can also drag you down.  Glad you are sharing your yucky feelings. Not a bad shout to just have a good old cry! Things usually look a bit brighter after.  Big hugs,  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Really fed up

Posts.Content: Hey Rebecca, Although I do not wear contacts, i do wear glasses. I have found especially week 3 my eyes have been extremely tired and dry. I took to wiping them with cotton wool buds and water. I even took the glasses off at times, because I felt my eyes just didn't want to focus. Seemed like hard work.  So, I would play it by ear - or by eye! SEE how it goes .... (oh I like this!) (God I need a life ...) Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Contact Lenses

Posts.Content: hey Ro, The beginning is VERY frustrating and VERY scary. You know you have that beast inside of you, and you are scared it is causing more damage as you wait for results.  The good thing is: in today's day and age there are so many angles, there is so much detailed information available to us now, that for many of us there is a really chance that we can beat this monster. - However, the medical experts need to take their time to really dig to the bottom of YOUR situation. No one person is the same.  I wish you and everyone else here from the bottom of my heart that you find you can truly trust your medical team! In that case, now that you are in their hands, they are going to do their utmost to get you back on the road of recovery! And you can trust that they are already doing so, even though you are still sat frustrated on your sofa!  The cancer cells, although growing fast in some instances, don't actually grow that fast! there is time to do this properly! Trust!  And then let go! - We are control freaks. We sort out the family, we run our lives, and then we suddenly come to this wall! Or as you put it this roller coaster! You have no option, but to get into one of the cars, and then it takes off - and all control is taken away! And not just control, but also predictability, and anticipation! You don't know what's coming next, you didn't ask for it, but jumping off is not an option either!  Sooooo, hold on to the ride! And just take every little bit as it comes. Don't look far ahead, just up to the next bend.  And then, use all your lovely people who are in your life to make this ride as comfortable as possible! That's the bit where you can take charge again. Let people know what you need, how you want to do this crap. Let them know how you feel, yes, bad times as well!  Acknowledging your bad times, I believe, gives you options to deal with those. You can spend time crying, throwing Plates (oh yesssss!! Very therapeutic) and then your brain gives itself the healing powers to buckle up again and have another go!  Hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: emotions arghhhh

Posts.Content: Hi Tracey,  I get the feeling we shouldn't be allowed back on our bikes for at least a year post bootcamp!! I have made contact with Mother Earth - Actually bloody concrete - twice since chemo! But then I blame it on the stupid cleats, which bolt your foot to the pedals! After the second fall, I have gone back to ordinary pedals, except they are purple now! Feeling much safer now! lol  As for the advice on the Tamoxifen, it keeps popping up again and again: try a different brand? Or else, try taking some Vit D, that apparently is meant to be really good for joint pains. problem with taking Brufen or similar on a regular I think may invite other issues, like stomach bleeds in the long run.  Good idea to go see your doctor about that. Oh, and make sure you invest in a bike helmet! ;) Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Appt with ONC Thursday

Posts.Content: actually, the nose bleeds wasn't something that I had not been prepared for, and as they came on it unsettled me. The explanation behind this is that the hair follicles in your nose have gone, and there is no protection atm. It's just thin skin, which can easily rupture.  I was advised to use vaselin, but don't know whether that helped, because I don't tolerate much in my nose anyway. Just a word of caution though: do not use any nose drops - very tempting if you have a blocked nose! They Burn!! It's hideously sore!  My nose did recover after chemo. So, one of those temporary effects, which is of no value to you just now, I am sure!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: sore head and bleeding nose

Posts.Content: Oh dear, being depressed is not a good state to be in at any time. Been there myself as we live in Aberdeen, and we get very long depressing dark winters.  I have had only a few lymph nodes removed, but, like yourself I am still finding there is a long thin muscle which seems to pull along the inside of the upper arm.  I am on about the same timeline as you. Found my lump on Easter Sunday! Had my diagnosis beginning of May and my op on the 19th of May.  As for the muscular pain in the arm, I do stretches. Always stretching against the pain, for as often as you can do and for as long as you can cope with. For example, running your arm up a wall, or holding onto the door arch above you. - But not stretching tooooo far, you want to make it feel like a stretch, not cause yourself pain or injury!  As for the gym - I have opted for regular walking instead. I have dogs anyway. But I have found chemo quite a tiring exercise, so going to the gym sounds to me too energetic. Apart from that, there are people with germs!!!!  So, combining your need for exercise and combatting depression: there is nothing better than good old proper sunlight and fresh air! - And you can make the walks as long or as short as you can cope with on any one day. And since you say you are supported by family: get them involved, take them out for walks with you. That way you are not walking alone, and you get time to chat with people. Also that way, you can say, when you are at home, and you don't want visitors, keep them to your walks.  Sending positive thoughts and light, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: GYM

Posts.Content: hey Lindsey Anne, Nah, there are no martyr on this site! There is no-one here who hasn't been shaken to their core when they were expecting a diagnosis or had it confirmed. It's a tough time for you just now, and your responsibility as a single mum must be playing extra hard on your emotions. But, it is true, if you can, take a deep breath and just look at a step at a time. And your first step is to just find out what exactly is going on. So far you have done everything you can do, and getting an appointment for next Friday is not too long to wait. Find things to occupy yourself with maybe, so you can pass the time more easily. Maybe you can go treat yourself a little, and your son! - And if you cannot sleep, go find a girly book, and just sit and read instead of tossing and turning. And you can come on here any time too, and just say it as it is. I believe these things are better dealt with when you put them out on the table for you to see. Once you spill it all out, then you are aware of your worries, and then you can find ways of coping! It is just a case of finding how to cope again. When you are the rabbit in the headlights, there is not much you can do, until the car swerves and goes past you. Thinking of you, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Breast thickening and further tests

Posts.Content: hey,  I opted for shaving, when my hair started to fall out. When we shaved it, it was sort of loose anyway, and it came out really easily. So, I would be surprised if it hurt her. I imagine the weight of the hair as is might be painful, so she may well be better off having it shaved.  As for pain relief, I'd try a bag of frozen peas (in a towel, so as not to burn her skin). And then use some E45 to gently massage into the scalp. That should have a soothing cooling effect.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: very tender scalp due too chemo...suggestions?

Posts.Content: Hi,  wow you do have your plate full to the brim. And I agree, this is  such a tough time, waiting for results. And as you must have been waiting for your son's results a year ago, it is not just the not knowing, but you feel you do know, because all your knowledge and recent experience hit you in the face. Just when you can neither fight nor run!  Our body and mind is prepared for fight or flight - it is not prepared to twiddle thumbs. It's what I call Shock, the inability to start dealing with your situation.  Once you know, then you can get yourself set up to do what needs to be done. But this is no-mans-land. A minefield and you are stood right in the middle of it.  From my experience the nights are the worst. Time when everyone is asleep, and you are exposed to thoughts, memories and anticipation.  I bought books. All sorts! Romantic trash. For me it was a case of looking for some escapism during that time. Other times I would just cry. Bawl my eyes out in the middle of Heathrow airport, as we were boarding a flight for a once in a lifetime holiday for our silver wedding anniversary! What a anniversary that turned out to be! We spent ten days away, as we were waiting for the results. It was hell on Earth, and it was also a very conscious period of my life. I was very aware of my experiences. And when I needed it I just cried, until I had cried myself out, and there was space again for hope and trust.  I do hope your boy is doing well now.  Hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Shock

Posts.Content: Congrats to your graduations from Bootcamp, ladies! Well done indeed! Time to celebrate (and let your hair down??? - well, it's the first day of regrowth!!) I am fine on Tamoxifen, except for the hot flushes! It's maybe a case of switching makes, if you are getting a hard time. But just wait and see. Might be a walk in the park after Bootcamp. Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: last chemo!!!!!

Posts.Content: It does sound like a side effect, doesn't it?! Yes, I think i would go to the GP, I wonder if you can get changed onto another brand! Might help.  In the meantime, what do you think about taking Vitamin D supplements? Apparently they may stem the side effects of joint pains. Might be worth a shot.  Good luck!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: side effects from anastrazole please any advice?

Posts.Content: Hey Alison, Great idea, well done for all the initiative!  I have sent you a friend request in fb.  However, other than the bold head, which I am very proudly presenting ... do I qualify when I still have two breasts? - Even though there is a small chunk missing in the one now ....  And, do photographers come all the way up to Aberdeen?????? Cold up here!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Amazonian Warriors - Challenge - Who wants to be in a calendar ??

Posts.Content: arrrgh. NAILS!!! I am still having issues with my finger nails, and yet I didn't even do Tax! 'Just' FEC. Mine are really soft and they just rip and break. - Not that you needed to know that. Except, you are not on your own.  I agree seeing the chiropodist sounds like a good idea. At least they might have some advice on what to do.  Let's hope there is eventual improvement!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Brittle nails

Posts.Content: arrrgh. NAILS!!! I am still having issues with my finger nails, and yet I didn't even do Tax! 'Just' FEC. Mine are really soft and they just rip and break. - Not that you needed to know that. Except, you are not on your own.  I agree seeing the chiropodist sounds like a good idea. At least they might have some advice on what to do.  Let's hope there is eventual improvement!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Brittle nails

Posts.Content: hey Sascha, if only we could take half a gaze into our future. Maybe that would make things easier - but probably not. So, back to the here and now. I know when I am not feeling well, i like to be in my bed, in my four walls. Not feeling like I am imposing. Just being ME. Baggy clothes and all!  You sound so alone on your path just now, amidst crowds of well-meaning people. As you are taking care of your own treatment plan as well, you are carrying very heavily on your own shoulders. At a time when we feel that we just want someone else to take some of the heavy load off us, help carry, you are struggling so much on your own. This sounds hard!  Take heart that you are doing the best you can! You are making all the difference to yourself, and you should be very, very proud of yourself! Go back to first principles though: one day at a time - or even just one hour at a time. Temperature makes us feel low - so, can you get that back under control? Do you have pain? Try get that sorted as best. And as for ironing your blobby hills .... that's just made me laugh - soooo sorry! I don't know, sounds like you need a G&T, that'll smooth the edges out - easy!  Take good care of yourself, love yourself and be proud!  Sending hugs and energy. Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Feeling blue

Posts.Content: Congratulations on your pregnancy with your twins. You must be over the moon. And I bet there was a time, not too long ago when you didn't think you even had a life to live.  Mastectomy or not ... the breastfeeding chorus is out there, to and against and just opinionated!  Like your first lot, these are YOUR babies to take care of, as best you can. And I am sure you will be making all the right decisions and all the same mistakes none of us caring mums ever make. lol  Your babies won't love you more or less because you can or cannot breastfeed. The difference in your ability to connect with them, is through your love to them, and through your confidence in looking after their needs!  Situations change, and yours has. You won't necessarily be able to do what you did with your previous babies, but you will find your way through. It's all about adaptability and flexibility. You'll be fine. You have done it all before.  I imagine you must be feeling quite tired and emotional as well now, with all these little lives in and around you. Make sure you take time out for yourself, and don't get yourself upset at what other people think or say - spend your energy on those that love you - and they won't judge you. As for formula milk on prescription: hmmm, I doubt it, but why not ask? You never know!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Advice needed breastfeeding / double mastectomy...

Posts.Content: Hey, I have had a week's worth of boosts as well after my 15 normal tannings.  You are right, they are focussed on the tumour area, and they burn much more shallow.  However, i can't confirm the bit about your chest wall and margins. In my case as far as I know my margins were clear. My lump was in the bottom quarter of my left breast, and I do only have fairly small boobs.  But I thought the boost was just a straight forward alternative to the general toasting, and since the alternative is still somewhat unexplored, they do both!  Hope that helps.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Extra week of radiotherapy due to tumour close to chest wall

Posts.Content: Hey Jonesy,  As far as I understand GPs specialise themselves in certain areas before they become GPs. My own GP is a gynaecologist. So there might be a qualified background to him/her that this is more than an educated guess to them.  I have made a different experience though: my GP acknowledged my lump, told me that it was good I had come with it straight away, and he would make an urgent referral! So, my GP did not make the call, but I am sure he included it in his consideration.  My surgeon made the diagnosis 3 weeks later after he had taken biopsies and syringed fluid off it. And then it still took until the bugger was out, and was sent off for histology to really know what exactly we were dealing with.  Maybe there are dead set tell tale signs even to a GP that he can make such a call. It's huge, if he/she is wrong though!  Glad you are getting the referral, and maybe you can go along with your mum, and help her get through this next period of time, which is so filled with uncertainty and angst for her and for you.  Hope this helps a little,  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Can GP tell if a lump is cancer?

Posts.Content: Hi Butterfly, Welcome to our group of very select people! I am so sorry you have to find yourself here too. ME and cancer - I have no personal experience, but my gut feeling tells me you are about to enter very muddy waters, if you are trying to separate the two. As you say ME is all about exhaustion, well, maybe cancer treatment is another form of ME. I would just take one step at a time, and work closely with your medical team. I am also wondering about work: it can be tough going when you are going through Bootcamp. At the same time, it gives you a sense of normality, something to keep your head above water. Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: New to Group

Posts.Content: hey Sheila,  Yes, I agree with Mistymoley, you would be going to your GP and ask for a second opinion, I would have thought.  I am just wondering, is there anything specific just now that you are worrying about? 2011 is 2 or 3 years ago. Is this worry just wearing you down, to the point that you are asking now, or do you have a specific symptom or result which you are not happy about? You also have the option of ringing up the nurses here on the helplines. They may be able to advise you, too, as to what is your best way forward from here. Hope you find peace of mind soon enough. It's tough without having to be doubtful! Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: worried about misdiagnosis

Posts.Content: Hey Rebecca,  Oh dear, not the waiting game again ....  Sounds to me you are quite worried. And so having to wait for a week does seem endless, yet again. In the meantime, I would try and get in touch with the oncologist or even your BC nurse. Chances are the GP would be referring you back across there anyway, if he thought there was something to be investigated.  You might like to ring the nurses here as well. They may be able to ease your panic a bit as well, if this is something and nothing. You can still catch them now, before 8pm!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Who you gonna call?

Posts.Content: Poor you!  I can't comment on the oedema, but with regards the tightness: do your stretches! 3 times a day. Just keep on holding against that tightness, without hurting yourself though, and you will find it gets better with time.  Probably be wise to have the oedema checked out though, cause you don't want it to get worse either!  And probably wearing lose clothing, so you don't feel restricted too much, might be an idea.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Painful arm - invisible cording? Lymphodoema?

Posts.Content: Hey you, Is the house not shifting? - Try sitting on a building site!  I must admit I would try things like diazepam as a very last option. I take it you have run out of wine, and just having a paddy isn't doing it either.  Our wonderful drop-in up here offers complementary therapies. And I think they are a wonderful option and addition to the general treatments. Apart from the relaxation in the treatment, the ladies are solo good at listening. So you can just have a real good go at putting the world to rights again.  But also, just removing yourself physically from the 'frontier', getting away from it, gives you space and time to refocus, to let go.  And focussing on the getting away: retail therapy, even if you don't go buy anything. Or taking the weekend away. Just by yourselves. Pack the dogs and go walk along a long beach. Let the wind blow some of that headache out.  And believe that what you have chosen to do is the right move. Yes, it's sticky just now, but how much more will you welcome the outcome, when eventually it all falls into place.  Patience? What's one of those?! Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Can anyone help me with suggestions for medication helping with stress...

Posts.Content: hey Caroline, What a relief!  I know diabetes has its own caveat of issues, but a good diagnosis is the first step in the right direction. Now you all just have to learn to adjust - no chocolate for Easter??? Oh well. The trials.  So pleased for you and your family. Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: not really to do with my bc but so upset

Posts.Content: Crying in IKEA is GOOOOOD! I cried at Heathrow airport! And I let it all out, all the fear and all the uncertainty. It does help to cry. It makes you unburden, at least for a little period of time, to gather more strength for things to come. And, if you were lucky enough like me to have your husband there with you at your cries, then I believe it's good to have that intimate sharing time! (Not the one where everyone shouts 'get a room'!) Things are so scary for you at the moment, because there are so many 'I don't knows'. But you are on the road to better days already, having had some surgery out of the way - the crap they've removed can't touch you any more! And the next stage of figuring what and where is scary whilst you don't know, but in the long run you will know, and it seems 'better the devil you know'.   HER2 pos makes the cancer more aggressive, but also much better treatable. So, choose the good from the bad in that! I do! I am starting my 3 chemo on Thursday, got RT ahead of me still, Tamoxifen and the Herceptin. All stuff you are going to be meeting on your long journey too. But, don't worry about all that later on. Just go with what's happening right now in your life. That's enough to cope with at any stage. And there is so much support here for you, as we are all travelling similar journeys. Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Different day, different diagnosis. Now it is HER2+

Posts.Content: Go scream!!!!! This is exactly the right place to do so.  You poor thing. you really do have your fair share of trouble all around.  Do the docs know why your daughter has the swelling? Did she take a knock or are you looking for a tumour as well?  It is soooo scary, isn't it, when it affects our 'kids'. We cope much better when it is ourselves.  But don't muddle it all up: you ARE getting there yourself. You have had your battle, and you are just getting scary emotional overspill from that! That is totally to be expected.  As for being cursed, I see where you are coming from. At the same time though, you are mentioning your 7 month old grandchild ... He/she would have been born in the thick of your diagnosis/treatment. That surely is a blessing, a wonderful little creature, who can give you all strength and hope and trust in the future.  It is just a 'blip'. Hold on to that. And get your strength from your strong family bonds. You will all get through this! Just one day at a time.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: not really to do with my bc but so upset

Posts.Content: hey Babs, Thanks for sharing. haven't got any symptoms as yet. But it does make a lot of sense. Unfortunately.  I wonder if there are any creams you can apply. And what about the age old thing of life yogurt to cultivate the fauna and flora down below?  Hope you get it sorted soon enough.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: bladder problams on tamoxifen?

Posts.Content: Hey Rozzie, Well done on completing bootcamp!  Although you are celebrating 7 weeks since the last chemo though, remember how long each cycle has taken to go through. Your body would only be ready for the next onslaught after 3 weeks, sometimes maybe even after 4. So, 7 weeks is still very much the time that your body is experiencing the after effects of chemo. And you have got to just be patient.  Some effects may stick around for quite a while. Or they may reoccur: the twitching of the eye, that is something I get now off and on on my right eye. I guess it has something to do with changes from the chemo. And when the eyes get tired then they start straining, they get runny and they twitch.  Your body has been run down to bare minimum functioning. You feel exhausted in yourself, but all the little areas that make up your body have that same experience too. Each one needs to go through the recovery now. Slowly and gently.  You will get there.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Side effects of chemo

Posts.Content: Yeah, travel was wonderful. Such an amazing place.  Just wondered, whether you might like to pose your question to the Life after Cancer group as well?! Just click on the link.  D xx
Posts.Title: Can anyone help me with suggestions for medication helping with stress...

Posts.Content: hey guys, Interesting question.  my response is as ever: go with the flow!  I found during each cycle that my body very much told me what I needed! I had periods of fasting, because the body just said no thank you. And I had periods of strange cravings!  I don't think bootcamp is served any better by torturing yourself into making dietary changes because it might say so in a book. If you feel you need to eat, then your body and your brain are telling you they need the energy. And fasting does lower your energy intake!  At the same time, there is nothing wrong with going without for a day or two, if you just feel yucky.  Go with the flow.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Fasting and chemo

Posts.Content: Hey Rachael, Like you I had been pretty scared of Tamoxifen - was going to rename it "Toxifen"!  As has been said, the problem, if there are any appear to be the fillers. That's the stuff they put in to bulk up the drug to make it into a tablet.  I am now on my 2nd packet - so, nearly 2 months in. I went to Boots, as that seemed to have been a recommendation on this site, and they have given me 'Wockhardt'. I am absolutely fine on these, and am intending to stick with them as long as they keep on being fine.  Neither my GP nor my Oncologist had any worries of me taking it. They do not appear to see the same level of treat. - And so the benefits still  very much outreach the problems. I will go with this treatment for now, because I do want to give myself all the chances that are thought out for me by professionals, who have my best interest at heart. I must trust in their knowledge and their research. What comes along, will come along. And then I will deal with that. But for now, all is very well. - Hot flushes, yes, but then, I have had those since I started chemo, so can't blame that on the tablets. It's just the side effect of getting older! If we want to beat cancer, and any other diseases that stop us in our tract to enjoy life, then, I figure, I have to put up with some side effects. And so long as they don't interfere with my general thirst for life, I will gratefully accept. Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: has anyone had any possive experiences with Tamoxifen????? Am due...

Posts.Content: hey,  what are you trying to achieve?  I find my bt mail box gets emails sent from certain groups, but all I can do is read them. To answer or respond I have to go into the Macland group, sign in and then write a response.  Are you finding that something is not working the way it used to? In that case you might want to switch it off, reboot and switch back on. See if that has sorted the problem.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: emails

Posts.Content: I am so sorry you feel so crap just now! And in the middle of the night, it makes it all seem much worse, doesn't it, because we feel so isolated. Just when you know you need your sleep, it feels all wrong to be sat up and feeling lousy.  I was just wondering about your itchiness, when you were talking puppy. It is just a straight guess, but have you checked your house for fleas? They can sit in the carpet as well, apparently for some time. And with your low resistance to anything just now, it doesn't take much for you to flare up like a balloon.  Have you thought of taking an antihistamine, to see if that calms it down? Apart from that, I would definitely try and see your doctor asap. There is no need to suffer unnecessarily! - Obviously I don't know, if it is unnecessarily, but if it is, then to hell with it. You have enough on your plate right now as it is.  Big hug, hope you are feeling a little comforted. Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Red itchy welts/bumps all over head and arms is this another gift...

Posts.Content: if you find a cure for that - I would be interested! lol I was never able to click directly. Am using an apple, so I don't know whether that's why.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: emails

Posts.Content: hey guys, This is cool. :D I had posted onto the 'group chat' for Scottish Group. And found very little.  So this is great news! - Sorry, obviously not that you all had to find your way on her too...  I am in Aberdeen. And I don't mind driving! Would be great to meet some of you in person.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Any Scottish ladies out there?

Posts.Content: Hey Janet, I don't think Glenrothes is totally out of the way. If you want to pm me, that might be a start! I do fb as well.  I have finished my bootcamp and tanning now. Finished with it all on Boxing Day! So, now I am experiencing 'life after'.  Would be good to get in touch.  And question about the 'breast friends' on Facebook. Does anyone know of any groups in Aberdeen?  Thanks, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Any Scottish ladies out there?

Posts.Content: Hey kathleen, as Flower says, if there is a group in Glasgow, then that's a good start for you.  However, I must admit I haven't unearthed anything like that in Aberdeen as yet, and so any contact would be brilliant from my point of view.  If you'd like to pm me, then maybe we can figure something out. Have you got Facebook? that seems to be an easier forum to chat more personally. And I am now trying to make some connections across Scotland, as I think there appears to be a bit of a demand.  Hope to hear from you, or anyone else for that matter, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Any Scottish ladies out there?

Posts.Content: Hey only you, It's NOT only you. Your breast tissue is changing with the tanning. It does get hard around your scar, because that is the area that is being targeted.  Imagine a chicken breast raw, nice and soft. and then cook it! It's exactly the same.  I think what might be a good idea is what I had done: I was also very worried. Especially as I had found my lump myself, and found it by comparing one breast with the other. Since tanning, your two breasts are not going to have the same texture again, and I don't think they ever will. But, having spoken with mu oncologist about that, he very carefully 'showed me around' my new/old breast. Showing me, making me feel what it feels like and explaining why.  It's basically getting newly acquainted with your breast. But, I would be pretty certain that there is nothing to worry about. Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: is it just the scar?

Posts.Content: hey George, you are so sweet. And maybe this is something that Marg is indeed going to attempt. - Let me know if you succeed!  For now, I am happy enough with my lazy option of leaving it as it is. The advantage is, I am not tempted when I am out and about to be answering Macland mails.  I designate time and space to come here. So, at the moment it suits me to get posts sent to my email, which I may find important. But then I respond from my laptop.  So, thank you, George. It's good to know there are people out there like yourself, who find these computer issues a bit of a challenge.  I am afraid, I use my laptop like I drive my car - I am not all that interested what is under the bonnet, until I hit a problem! lol (I hear my husband grumbling! Engineer that he is!) Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: emails

Posts.Content: Do you trust your surgeon???? If he says he can do it, then I imagine so long as you trust him, then he can do it!  It all depends on how much you feel you need this op to feel more like yourself again, I guess.  I hope you do get some responses here from people who have had to make that same or similar decision. Difficult though, because we are all different. And just because something worked for one person doesn't mean it does for the next.  Another factor to consider is your health and your young age! If you are a fit and healthy person in every other way, then your body is able to cope all the much better.  Good luck, hope you come to a decision which works for you.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Can i have surgery on a previously radiated breast ?

Posts.Content: I agree Marie, although, I must admit I wasn't up to much keeping fit during chemo. But we did go out for walks with the dogs. Nice gentle exercise. Keeps the mood up, and it made me feel good about myself, even if it was just 5 minutes round the block. But it also gets the old adrenalin flowing and it keeps all the circulation up to speed.  So whether swimming or running or just walking - getting out there is good medicine!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Exercise

Posts.Content: I agree Marie, although, I must admit I wasn't up to much keeping fit during chemo. But we did go out for walks with the dogs. Nice gentle exercise. Keeps the mood up, and it made me feel good about myself, even if it was just 5 minutes round the block. Posts.Title: Exercise

Posts.Content: Well done Kiera for getting back into the gym. I had to laugh at the thought that running gets easier with less weight. I struggle at best of times, but I have only had a lumpectomy - so, there is no chance that my running will be any better now.  I am a swimmer, and after having now not been in the water since the Spring I am really looking forward to going again sooooon. Because of the rads my skin is sensitive, and I am just wanting to wait a little longer to make sure the chlorine isn't going to aggravate anything.  My daughter has been running for life for quite a few years now. And last year people have been extra generous on account of my BC. Even people I have never met. It was quite humbling. Well done all you who go out there running their feet off for cancer research!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Exercise

Posts.Content: hey Catherine, I had my last chemo-bootcamp on the 19th Oct., but then I went for rads after that. And during rads you are not meant to go swimming either. So that's why its been such a long time. I have had my last tanning on Boxing Day, so I am thinking that maybe next week is 2 weeks past, it would be safe enough to go for a first dip. I am still applying heaps of aqueous cream anyway. As for bold head ... yeah, that has crossed my mind as well, but I now have baby fluff, which at least looks a little more like the real deal. But I was also concerned that it would feel colder, and that I may have to wear a cap... But I don't think so. the problem is going to be the distance from the changing rooms to the pool. I think once I am in the water noone will be looking anyway. And I just love the fresh ambition of learning to swim!!! It's never too late!!! I am proud of you! Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Exercise

Posts.Content: hey guys, I have not had tax. I had FEC. My last one was in October. And today I went to my hairdresser's for the first time! What an outing! I was so nervous - I am very protective of my curls now. But they are kind of unruly and my hairdresser agreed that the hair is coming in at different lengths in different areas around my head. So she carefully thinned out at the back, but she didn't touch the top at all.  Made a huge difference. Even though there really isn't all that much to cut yet. And then she said I did have to pay anything. - Huge awe!! So so lovely!  Anyway, apart from it taking nearly 12 months from the last chemo, my tip of the day is: make a photographic diary for yourself. As most people have iPhones, it is easy to do selfies! Kepp them for yourself, dated, so that you can eventually see your progress. Because progress seems kind of slow and subtle, you might just get fed up with waiting. But when you look back and compare, on a 'bad hair day', it's good psychology to have the reference! Also, if you are brave, post the hair progress on Facebook. Let your friends be part of your regrowth. It will stop them asking stupid questions! And they may be full of admiration!  Dorothee xx

Posts.Content: Thinking of you today and tomorrow, Annabel, I am so glad you are about to start the chemo too just now - sorry, being very selfish here, and not really glad for your sake.  I am going in 2 weeks, and I am starting to really dread it.  Can't seem to quite get my head around the hair loss yet either. In respect to not having any and then meeting people who I know, but don't feel I need to tell just now what I am going through. It's none of their business.
