Just need a neon glowing arrow hanging above me, lol.  I didn't realise you would be getting 'a tour' first. Sounds like when I was pregnant, and we got the tour around the delivery suite weeks before. But maybe that's not a bad thing. And least I would know on the day where I am going to be.  Are you taking someone with you? And is it advisable to take a taxi? Or can I drive myself home after?  Look after yourself, be brave Dorothee x
Posts.Title: First chemo tomorrow

Posts.Content: hey Molly, and everyone, No, I am not going with the cold cap, I don't think.  I am thinking, just go brave it. Have it over and done with. Going cold turkey, as it was.  We'll see.  Oh, and Molly, I am a dyslexic myself. So, don't you worry about your spelling - it's what you say, not how you spell it, that's important!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: First chemo tomorrow

Posts.Content: what wonderful News.  And what an amazing oncologist! truly caring!  Now for all the treatment to come you are so much more energised!  Happy Christmas Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Best Christmas news!

Posts.Content: Hi Mollydog, Unfortunately, I can relate to the pain in the breast area. And my op was 2 years to the day today! (Yay, I am free of the cancer for a whole 2 years now!) I also had 'tanning', and I am pretty sure that the radiation/toasting has gone right into the ribs! Fully fried, and the rib cage is still sore 2 years on. It has got a wee bit better, but as I am now exercising, I also find that building up muscles in the chest area just feels 'different'!  Unless it is really painful, which is limiting your daily activities, I have found I just recognise that the pain is there at times. And I am pretty sure I understand why. So, I am okay with that. It's like having my very own battle scar! A reminder of what things I have had to deal with.  If, however, you are experiencing pain you are worried about, or pain, which you are not really able to tolerate, then I would go back to your GP, and have a chat. You shouldn't be going through life in unnecessary pain! And sometimes just knowing what is going on makes the pain feel less severe!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: breast pain

Posts.Content: I agree, definitely get it checked out. You know it isn't NOTHING! But you are second guessing as to what it might be! Be brave, get it looked at! And then you know.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: A new lump

Posts.Content: Hey guys, drinking plenty is really good! And really difficult, I seem to remember. I ended up trying all sorts of juices, as I couldn't tolerate caffeine very well, and I just don't like drinking plain water. I used to make a chart every day of writing down how much I had had. Really trying hard to get to 3 litres, and failing miserably on several occasions.  I found though that a lot of what I experienced seemed to take me right back to the faddyness of pregnancy! and so I am wondering whether your sense of smell is maybe heightened as well just now, and you are experiencing much more of a bad smell, just like your taste buds are all over the place! I am sure your red dye can't be smelling the most lovely smell, but maybe your sense of smell is playing a little trick on you too.  Unless you are getting a burning sensation when passing urine, I wouldn't worry, and just go spray perfume around the room! - I have done that! Really expensive as well. lol  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: urine smell

Posts.Content: Hey, I have done 6 FEC. On the last one I was coughing my lungs out like mad, and I had a stinking cold, but the bloods were fine! So we did it anyway.  After my 1st and my 4th I had a delay by a week, and that was because I went neutropenic both times. No colds though and not feeling rough. Just spiked a temp and that was that.  You'll be fine, I bet. Go for it and get it over with. Another one crossed off the list of to-dos.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: what delays chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi Ethel! Yay, nice one! Although, I am with OhmyG: husband is a keeper! He has been and still is my absolute rock, soul mate and partner in crime! Couldn't have done it as well as I did without him.  But, yes, lots on my list, too:  my self confidence is solid now. I don't get wound up as easily. I prioritise and drop what is not important to me. I have patience and listening skills to help people who are in similar situations. I have made, very unexpectedly, a number of very good friends. I am an Annabel's Angel now. I am running and exercising now - 5k is now happening!  Talking of which ... I am going to be walking the Moonwalk this year in Edinburgh. My lovely son is coming along with me! So looking forward to it. - If anyone of you ladies is able and wanting to join us, please feel free to pm me! I'd love to get a group together! In the meantime, can I share my JustGiving page, please.  Hugs all around, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Almost 2 years on - the good things!

Posts.Content: hey Pat, What a palaver! I think I am with you on the fact that they maybe could have been more efficient right from the start. But then, maybe they couldn't. - I wonder if you could ask your consultant that question!  Is it inefficiency that delayed the findings of the further lumps, or is it greater efficiency, because the newly found lumps are much smaller, and they had needed to look at the scans in much more detail.  Does it make any difference to the treatment you have been receiving so far? Did they just do a couple of lumpectomies, and you are now looking at going to have another two removed on the same breast? Hope you get it sorted soon. I do feel for you. Just when you think they have got it all! Doesn't leave you with much confidence, does it?! Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Delay with Diagnoses

Posts.Content: heyJulie, I never had to do Tax, I did 6 FEC. It sounds to me like your oncologist was weighing things up. Some people seem to cope better than others, and Tax is meant to be a tough one in the mix of things. So, very well done for coping so well.  My FEC didn't go to plan, and my oncologist basically had a think the other way round after No4, saying that in other countries it is quite the norm apparently to just go with 4. England and Scotland like to go with 6, if they can get away with it.  There has got to be a bit of give and take, I think. Because of the aggressiveness of the cancer cells, they like to throw everything at the body that they can, in the hope and trust it will irradiate everything. But on the other hand, there has to be a limit, when the body is no longer coping and is starting to self-destruct!  Sounds to me like your oncologist is saying your body is coping, so lets just make absolutely sure!  Good luck on the last ones. Each and everyone is bootcamp! But you are getting there!!! Good on you!  As for taste and texture. Sorry, can't help there either. Try pineapple, it seems to work with others too. It will get better again! :)  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Chemo changed from 4 TC to 6!!

Posts.Content: sounds to me like you are not just at the end of your tether, but you are also at a turning point in your life!  We do not come out the same person. A very good friend of mine posted on here a couple of years ago the phrase "Upgrade". Yes, indeed, we are upgrades. We have matured! We have come to see the light! Our choices are more deliberate, and our awareness has received a focus it hasn't had before.  So, you are aware and you are desperately feeling that things cannot go on as they have done. Am I right?  How well do you communicate with your partner? really talk! You were saying you are walking with your friend, but not with your partner. - I agree, when you walk you talk! there is no getting away from it, and you have time, and nowhere else to be. It's a really good place to be in. We have two dogs, and so we have that time every day, when we make time to talk. It's not always something important, and don't get us started on politics ... But it fuses us back together.  Relationships evolve! just like you have become an upgrade, your partner will also have gone through changes with the redundancy. He may well feel a failure, not good enough. and he may be hiding this from you my shutting you out.  You are both needing support, I think. But you may not be strong enough, either of you, to be supporting the other on your own. - I would go have a chat with your GP. I would suggest you have a chat about possible depression, possible post traumatic stress!!! See what your GP might then come up with.  In the mean time, maybe a little time away is not a bad suggestion. Doesn't have to be expensive. Doesn't have to be far. When was the last time just you and your husband went away for a weekend??  Start small! Start by putting music on instead of the telly. get a bottle of wine out, and chat! Or run a very lovely bubble bath! with candles.  Find some ME time, and try and find some US time. - Or find a good friend to have a good heart to heart!!! Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Zoladex and Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: I wasn't meaning the anti depressants for yourself! I am wondering whether your husband is suffering depression.  D xx
Posts.Title: Zoladex and Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: excellent!  Here is the website for the Moonwalk Scotland. Have a look at the right hand side: it gives you options as to which walk you'd like to walk.  Personally, i am going for the Full Moon, that's the marathon distance. But there are options to go nuts on a shorter distance - or even further!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Almost 2 years on - the good things!

Posts.Content: hi sweetheart,  We are hearing you loud and clear! You are tired, you are in pain, you have lost yourself on the way to recovery, on the way to being alive.  Swapping a shitty existence for the threat of cancer - that's not a good swap!  But, genuinely, people around you may not realise. Or they may choose not to realise. - I don't know how old your children are, but my eldest wasn't able to support me when I had cancer a couple of years ago! He ignored the fact, and he was 22 years old then. I am not so sure that your kids are able and aware of your needs right now.  Your husband may very well love the strong woman in you! And you have shown him and yourself how very strong you can be, what you are made of! And in general, I think we are very poor at giving up control and leave things up to anyone else around us.  That is, until we come to breaking point! And at that we feel we have let everyone down, we have let our side down, we are weak, vulnerable, useless and very un-endearing!  You have gone through so much, and I imagine you have self confidence doubts, in the way you now look and with the past experience you have just had. We don't come out the way we go into battle! We change. But we like to hide it, because we lose confidence and self belief. Possibly.  It is time though as you realise to let your guards down. It is the right thing to do, even though you feel vulnerable. You need to let your husband SEE, he needs to know! Otherwise he cannot help you. And if your relationship is anything like mine with my OH, then let me tell you, sometimes they need to be hit with a barge pole!  A couple of weekends ago my husband and I went for a cycling ride. He is a good cyclist, and he is full of enthusiasm. I on the other hand do not ride very often, and I just do not have the muscle strength he has. So, we set off, and had a beautiful day of it. Until, after about 5 hours I completely ran on empty! I had nothing left. But I was not minded to let him know. I had come this far, I would manage! And then I came to yet another bleeding hill .... He cruised up .... And I tried! And then I stopped and I just cried! Really cried, and as he came back down the hill to see where I had got to, he looked shocked! Absolutely shocked! he had had no idea how much I had pushed myself.  I still made it home on my bike! Tbh, a really good cry out in the open was exactly the right thing! I felt so much better for it! And my husband took it more gently, was encouraging, and we had a good old laugh after. But he has since been commenting, he never thought he'd see the day he would 'break' me! Yeah!  Honey, you need some help in sorting out how you are feeling right now. And your first port of call may be your GP. Or your oncologist, to have a check up on the meds you are taking. You are right, the Zoladex may well be keeping the cancer out, but at what price just now? What are the alternatives? And what can be done to ease the pain???  And then there are people you may like to seek out who can listen to you. People who are not close family, and can take on board what you are telling them, without personal implications to them. I am talking counselling here, at outreach centres like Maggies Centre.  In the meantime, let rip here. Say how you feel, because it may help you to get your head around how you are feeling and why that is so. Don't be embarrassed, and don't feel you shouldn't be feeling this way! it's about time you let that cork out of that fizzing bottle, before it explodes or worse: breaks!  Hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Zoladex and Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: I feel you have covered it all yourself! You just don't really know, until you have done the first cycle yourself. And the waiting and the unknown at this stage are so frustrating, and so worrying.  I have just had my first round of FEC, and my body couldn't much cope. So, second week I spent in hospital, and third week I just felt hugely tired. Having said that, the oncologist is now looking to make changes to the treatment, so that round 2 is going to be less aggressive. So, I am looking forward to an easier ride from now on.  This, however, threw out my timetabled regime. For the week in hospital I won an extra week of recovery, so instead of a 3 week cycle, i am doing a 4 week cycle this time. Not a problem for me, but, if you are trying to anticipate regular hours, be prepared that things may change. You may have good days and bad days, or good weeks and bad weeks. It's definitely not all baaaaad. Just try and be flexible with it. And in general, I think, working is an excellent idea to get your mind off all the worry, but also, a straight forward fitness issue. I walk as much as I can, just to get that body exercised, to recover all the muscles and bones and the brain, as much as I can for the next round. Great though to hear you be so positive. That's a good ally to have by your side. Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Will I be able to work through treatment?

Posts.Content: Oh Annie, just let rip! Needs to come out! You sound soooo scared.  Good thing though, that you are finding your chemo is working! So, more chemo will in theory be working more! Is there any reason, why they shouldn't carry on firing with chemo, until full eradication? Obviously not forever with breaks. But, I would have a chat with your oncologist. Seems to me like, if you were to compare it with antibiotics, then, yes, you may say you can only be treated with antibiotics, but, there are variations of antibiotics and dosages, so it'd be a lifetimes worth of applying and re applying. But it wouldn't shorten your lifespan necessarily - you'd just be rattling with pills.  The thought of this cancer is very invasive in itself, isn't it. It's mind games! Have you found a counselling person yet? Or a yoga person? Sounds to me like you really need someone who can install a little inner peace again in yourself.  Big hugs from far up North. I am sending you all the peace of mind you can cope with, if that is what you are needing right now.  love, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Triple negative and lung mets, is there any hope? :(

Posts.Content: Morning Flower, I would go pester that GP of your again, or else, see if you can make an appointment with your oncologist.  Water retention is NOT putting on fat! And when you are saying you are constantly very thirsty, then I have alarm bells ringing about diabetes!!!  Definitely go back and have that checked out! Get a second opinion!  hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Weight Gain and Water Retention

Posts.Content: hahahahaha. Sorry, I am tired just reading all your activities. So good to see you have been having such a good and active time.  Running out of steam is just part and parcel of life! Bootcamp just makes us reach our limits a little sooner.  No way feeling guilty about what you have done and enjoyed is going to solve anything! You have had a fab time, and you so deserve it.  I would have thought your brother-in-law's party hasn't just been sprung on you. You knew it was coming up. And you made a perfectly reasonable choice. You didn't 'pace' yourself. You enjoyed what you did to the full. And you might well have considered beforehand that you didn't have much energy left by the end.  It's called prioritising! We can't do it all, and your sister knows that as well. Yes, she would be disappointed, but, her husband's birthday party will be great, whether you are there or not.  So, don't feel guilty. and don't push yourself! It's not worth it.  If they live close, then you may be able to just pop by for an hour. But, if your body says enough is enough, then you are better off listening and taking a duvet day.  During bootcamp our superpowers are just that little more limited. So it's best to acknowledge that and enjoy the best titbits out of a whole arsenal of parties and activities which this time of year has to offer.  Go put the kettle on, and stay in your PJs!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: tired

Posts.Content: Hi Anne, and welcome to our very privileged club.  I am so sorry you are struggling. And I have no personal experience with seroma. But from what I can tell, they suck! Big time!  I do hope you get to hear from people who can share personal experience. I am not so sure about any quick fixes when it comes to the list of side effects, sadly. But, have you tried a glass of wine, and a box of chocolates? - And then you just need to get over the depression of the scales!  I know this is no laughing matter, and the fact that it doesn't seem to improve just keeps you right down in the dumps.  When do you go back to have it drained again? Is it a daily outing just now?  I do feel for you, Hugs from afar, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Tiresome, depressing seroma

Posts.Content: hey Katharine,  Oh yes, letting go of that security blanket has two sides to it! You want to get rid, but it's kind of a lifeline which you have trusted to do its job.  Problem with this cancer treatment is, we have handed over all control to the medics, because we have been resigned to the fact that our body is incapable of making sensible decisions. Apparently it is broken, and is doing its own thing!  And here we are, suddenly having to start believing again that our body does know what it is supposed to be doing. It is quite capable to look after itself again. It just needed some help with the mopping up procedure! - It takes time to get that belief again, to feel 'safe' again within your own body.  If your consultant feels you should wait a little while for things to settle and recover before starting the next treatment, then that to me sounds like a good idea! Remember, although you have had your final tax today - YAY - it does take the three weeks, and more, now for this round to do its job, and then leave your system.  There is no rush, you have done all the hard work! give yourself time to start breathing again! All is well enough, and now comes the part of learning to ride that bike without stabilisers again!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: after chemo

Posts.Content: Sounds horrible! Also sounds like you are not getting much rest, when you itch like that all the time. Which probably makes it more of a vicious circle for you - getting tired, getting stressed, getting more itchy, too!  I was just wondering about taking an anti-histamine. Is that possible with your drug-concoction?
Posts.Title: MRI dye grrrrrr - 3 weeks on still itching like a crackhead

Posts.Content: well, then taking some anti histamine may not be a bad shout.  My daughter gets exema when she is stressed (I know it's not quite the same), itchy hands mostly. But it really gets her into a vicious circle. And it gets her so frustrated.  Her strategies are E45 and cooling down!
Posts.Title: MRI dye grrrrrr - 3 weeks on still itching like a crackhead

Posts.Content: Hi Ro5ieposie, I can see where you are coming from, I think. I get the impression you are feeling like you are sitting on a ticking time bomb.  If that is the case, then you are not going feel very relaxed about your circumstances.  My suggestion would be to go back to your oncologist, and to have a very frank conversation. Maybe you could talk this through first with your OH or a close friend, and then take them along to the meeting.  Your medical team have to be able to reassure you one way or the other that what you are doing or not doing is in fact the best possible solution for you.  If they are happy to leave well alone, then they must have good reasons for this, and maybe you are just not yet able to understand why the suggestion has been made to leave and watch.  Leaving and watching, though, is not the same as ignoring! And by the sounds of it, at the moment there is no need to have such a huge procedure done. After all, this is never just a little op. Your poor body really does get put through its paces every time it has to undergo and then recover from such a major operation.  But it's not all about the physical body, is it?! It's about your mental welfare as well. You need support, if not an op, to come round to being able to live with this situation as it is. That takes time, but it also takes reassurance by medical team and maybe by counselling support.  So, long speech here: I would go back and talk all your worries through. Listen carefully, and then make up your mind as to what you feel is best for you!  Good luck, it's not easy.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Anybody in the same position?

Posts.Content: Hey Marg,  I imagine this is individually different, because your hormones will react differently to the onslaught of the chemo.  Personally, I had a small period, nothing in comparison to the normal ones, and then that was it for me. A year on and they haven't come back either.  I do know from others that their periods restarted again after chemo was finished.  Out of all this mess - can't say I miss my periods! :)  Hope all goes well enough for you  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: periods after cemo

Posts.Content: On my first chemo round my neutrophils decided to go absent altogether! So, 0.8 is low, but ...  I did spend a week in hospital, because i got a temp, and then they started to treat the infection. So, again, just because your neutrophils are low, doesn't mean they are taking you in.  Neutrophils do recover again, but, it seems an extra week is a good idea. So my first cycle took 4 weeks instead of 3. But then after the 4th week I really did feel much better again, ready (if you can ever be) for the next dose.  After the neutrophils had got so low, the oncologist made adjustments to the treatment. In the end, yes, you want to kill the c-blighters, but on the other hand you don't want to damage anything like bone marrow unnecessarily! So, take the time, let the good stuff recover first! You need a good strong bone marrow in the long run!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Low Neutrophils

Posts.Content: Oh dear, your hormones are in the process of going through a blender just now. And someone pressed high speed!  You may not necessarily see the period which you are expecting. But the hormones are still pretending they have a relevant job to do. Basically: your system is fucked for a while! lol don't think there is a 'nice' word for it!  Get yourself on the sofa, and have a duvet day! Let everyone else sort Christmas out this year - it will still happen!  Hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: periods after cemo

Posts.Content: I have just done FEC 3. I did not opt for cold cap, and yes, the hair did start to come out by the end of week 2.  I got my eldest son on the job, and he shaved it all off, in our living room. I thought I might as well get a public viewing! - My family were so supportive. All agreed that I was still looking like myself, even without the hair.  And my youngest said the other day he preferred me without all the beanies and scarves I wear, because then he can see 'me'! What a lovely thing to say!  My eye-brows and my eye-lids still have all the hair left. Now, if that stays, then I  will be well happy, because it doesn't give me that 'naked' look in the face, when I go out.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: FEC and hair loss

Posts.Content: Hey Alexandra1,  I am sorry to see that you have had no response as yet to your question.  I must admit, I am not quite sure what it is you are having done. You you like to explain this a bit more to me? What is the MDT? And how do you reckon you know what procedures are likely to be chosen for your treatment?  Getting copied letters, which are meant for GPs and other medical people, I find that rather difficult to deal with. The medics all speak in their own language, and they are talking about you, but not to you, and yet you are reading it and you are trying to read in between the lines as well.  When do you next have an appointment with them? It seems to me that you might like to make a list of questions which really you are needing answers to.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Total duct excision

Posts.Content: You sound like you are well prepared, Gill! It's good to get started! Hope all goes well enough! And then you have only 5 more to go!  Go start bootcamp!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo Today

Posts.Content: hey Jessica, I feel for you!! The waiting periods really do your head in, don't they! Are they still waiting for results? It is so important to have all your results in, because the treatment is so specific.  But hopefully on Friday you get to find out. And then treatment might start quite quickly.  Sound silly, but, I think I would try and enjoy this week of waiting. Have an early Christmas dinner, just in case they start Chemo asap. Keep yourself busy, that makes the time go by faster, too.  Before you know it, you'll be in the grips of the treatment, I wish you all the best. Hope you cope well enough.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: jessica1

Posts.Content: Excellent news, Binny! So glad for you.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Bone Scan.

Posts.Content: Excellent news, Binny! So glad for you.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Bone Scan.

Posts.Content: ooooh congratulations!!  I am wondering, whether it will take a few weeks for things to 'settle down' though. And maybe your sunken area is going to right itself over time.  I am comparing with my lumpectomy. The breast kind of reformed itself over the year. Whereas in the beginning it really looked like there was an obvious part missing, it has kind of rounded itself up.  :) Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: I have a new nipple on my implant (reconstruction) but I now have...

Posts.Content: ooooh dear. You sound disappointed. :(  It's so brand new, and it was all you had hoped for, and then it looks 'faulty'.  If you are really concerned then there is nothing for it but to go back and have a chat! It wont make any difference I wouldn't have thought to make comparissons on this with other boobies, because you know whether you are okay with yours or not.  If he says, no can do, then you have to learn to live with it. But then, you have a boob again, which means you can go out and buy lovely bras again, without pouches and bits, that fall off.  And nobody else out in the world would know any different. - I am sort of thinking about when you decorate around the house: YOU know where the wallpapers don't meet properly or where the paint looks iffy! But nobody else does!  I am also wondering, I know you really like your art. Is there a little perfectionist who has a real eye for good lines and beauty? And you are presented with imperfection? - What do other people think? Go show off - after the watershed obviously! Get some feel for whether you are just being paranoid maybe?  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: I have a new nipple on my implant (reconstruction) but I now have...

Posts.Content: Hi Hannah, Welcome to our distinguished club. Sounds a bit serious to suffer black-outs. That can't be good. All else considering, you don't want to kill yourself knocking your head on the way down. I imagine it is a combination of your chemo, and maybe something like a low blood pressure. I have got low BP myself, but fortunately no black outs.  My suggestion would be to take it easy, get up slowly, keep digestives or similar by your side - a bit like low BP during early pregnancy. And definitely let your medical team know!  Oh, and are you drinking plenty???? I tried to drink about 3 litres a day. Wasn't always possible, but I did give it a good go. Loads of fluids to wash the toxins out of the system is so important.  And now you are through with the 'bootcamp', give it a little time, and hopefully things will settle back to something more manageable.  Hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: hiya I'm hannah and new to this site

Posts.Content: Hey guys, YES, rib pain!  Your ribs are roasted like spare ribs! There is damage caused! You  will find that your tissue is going to change as well. It gets darker and kind of hardens a bit. It is all the trauma caused by the tanning!  If you think, a broken rib is taking a loooong time  before it stops being sore. I think we are coming quite close to making a similar experience here. No break, but deep toasting.  As ever, if you are worried, then it is always a good shout to run it by your medical team. But, yeah, I think rib ache is part of the untold after effects list.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Rib pain and radiotherapy

Posts.Content: hey Maggie, Good to see they are taking it seriously. Will you let us know what the scan shows?! Good luck. keeping all fingers crossed is something NOT to worry about. Hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Rib pain and radiotherapy

Posts.Content: hey guys, I  feel quite worried for anyone out  there who may have found something and is not quite sure what it is. A report saying screening is dangerous is just not helping, because it might put people off going to have their lump checked out!  I think the problem is not the 'screening' in itself, but the resulting 'treatment'!!!!! Surely the scenting isn't at fault for how the lump is being treated!!!  Get the accuracy of the diagnosis improved and the treatment more sensitive to the requirement!!!!!  But don't stop inviting people to get screened - that would be a Huge step in the wrong direction!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: BBC Report

Posts.Content: I believe you may be suffering the steroid effect! I had the same problem, and it lasted for as long each cycle as I was taking the steroids. Once they were back out of the system I crashed and slept for 10 hours a go!  You are right, it feels like your body is exhausted but your brain just cannot switch off! I ended up cleaning house at 2am! Everything but throw the hoover about. I used to find other steroid sufferers online at the same time - quite a little community out there I reckon!  My doctor gave me sedatives to counteract this. However, I really really didn't want to take any more tablets than was absolutely necessary, so I just made to with not sleeping much.  Hope that helps a little. Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Not sleeping

Posts.Content: hey Amanda, Thinking of you. Hope you got good News on your results!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: A massive thank you to every one xxxx

Posts.Content: hey Lucy, Well done for having gone to your GP! And by the sounds of it, your GP has taken your lump seriously and has referred you. You are doing all the right things!  I imagine you are going to be meeting your specialist, and there are investigations going to happen. Possibly a mammogram, a scan, and then they may well take biopsies, too.  The results of all of these tests are going to be another little waiting game, but they ware really important, and determine how your specialist is going to go on from there.  DO keep in mind, that you may very well have something other than cancer. At this stage you really only know that you haven't got Nothing!  If it is, then, even though you will be guiding your way along your mum's history, there is so much that can be done! And no person is exactly like the next. Your life is different to your mum's. And you have taken every precaution!  So glad you have come on here to share. Waiting for News of this kind is never easy, but you will find people here have all experienced similar, and we are well qualified to listen and support you.  Hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Worried.... Any help appreciated!

Posts.Content: hahahaha, Rebecca, I LOVE the thought of your Bruce & Willis new boobs.  I am still stuck with my old ones, and one being slightly dishevelled, I think I would refer to mine as 'Lady and the Tramp' now!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Worried.... Any help appreciated!

Posts.Content: hi, I am sorry, I do not know anything about Exemestane. I was wondering whether you might get some info from the Macland nurses via the free helpline!  I am not a professional with regards pharmacy, but my guess with regards the different 'weight' of your tablets, is that they just bulk out differently. What I mean by that is: the medication, which you are needing to take is not pure! The tablet you take is a composite of the medication plus something else, which carries the medication and turns it into a tablet. So, you are not comparing equal strength, just by looking at the size of the tablet when you are comparing different medications.  Does that make sense?  Your doctor must have had reasons for swapping your tablet. Maybe you have had some side effects which he is hoping to loose, such as the tiredness. Some side effects are the result of exactly those bulking agents. So here is hoping that the new tablets don't affect your system as badly. Dorothee xx
