Posts.Title: Exemestane

Posts.Content: I don't think cancer cells are intelligent enough to set up a conspiracy against our bodies, as in, if we remove one 'playing field' then they just pack up and move into another one.  Having said that, once you have an established cancer in one region, then any 'floaters' would be settling somewhere other than removed breasts, if, in fact, that was where they were going to settle.  As far as I see it, primary cells originally start changing in situ. So, for someone who is tripple neg that might mean randomly anywhere. It would be secondaries, that find new homes through wandering.  As for removing both breasts in anticipation ... well, apparently Sharon Osborne did it. I imagine you are able to get this done privately if you so wish. Does it make sense medically? Does it make sense psychologically to yourself?  Let me address the latter first: I understand you are struggling with your own body image, with having had one breast taken off. So maybe, by removing your other breast you may think you may regain that balance, the 'sameness'. And it may work better for you.  As for medically: who knows? Your present cancer cells may jump ship, but then they may be kept contained. If they jump ship, they may jump anywhere OTHER than the other breast.  Would that cause you to wonder, if you could, whether in anticipation you might like to remove an organ, or part of your intestine, just in case?  Don't know if these thoughts are making any sense to you.  Much love Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Serious questions

Posts.Content: tbh, I don't know re mammogram as I was 46.  You will find Macmillan nurses on the end of a phone, if you want to find out some specifics. They will be able to tell you a lot more.  It IS a very scary time, I am sure, because you are not blissfully ignorant, as you say. But, seriously, you are NOT your mum! So, try and go from scratch! Wait for results, and then you know what you are dealing with. You talk about your family worrying as well, My suggestion would be for now, make that your ally! let people around you know how you feel. Ask for someone to go along to your appointment. It is a pretty scary experience, and there might be a lot of information exchanged. So two pairs of ears would be so much better!  I am not entirely sure about the Macmillan phone number for the nurses, but have a look, should be easy to find on this wonderful site.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Worried.... Any help appreciated!

Posts.Content: Lucy, I am doing fine now. I got my big scare a year ago - actually had my official diagnosis a year and two days ago.  I, like yourself, had found a lump in my one breast, and I also went to my GP with it. And thankfully, he also took it very seriously and I got referred to the specialists. First I saw a surgeon, who did all the investigation, and eventually my op, and then I got passed onto my very lovely oncologist.  I have also been very lucky with their support team: you will find the breastcare nurses so valuable for any extra support. They will be there for any questions you didn't remember to ask, and any extra time you need to get things through your head -  But let me not move beyond your next appointment - let's see what they say first. For me: long year. I did the 'bootcamp' and the 'tanning' and I am now on all sorts of aftercare 'stuff'. But: I am absolutely fine!  So, it can be done. - My dad also died of cancer, not even 5 years from my diagnosis. His was another cancer, he'd had non-hotchkin's lymphoma. - It kind of made it easier not to compare, because it was so obviously different. But, as I said before: you are YOU, not your mum. And I am still here!  Let me know how you get on.  Take care Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Worried.... Any help appreciated!

Posts.Content: So great to hear your news, Sascha. You have taken your battle into both of your hands, and you are inspirational! Great positive news on the pathology! What a huge difference the 20% make to the original 'estimated'? 90%! Holy cow, that's years off your back!  Keep going! And keep sharing! And are you back in sunny Spain? Send some warmth up the coast into Scotland, please!!!!!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Pathology Review

Posts.Content: Oh dear,  it feels to me like you have got yourselves into a flat spin here! Panicked by the urgency, and the feeling that you are both running out of time.  I would suggest to take a deep breath.  Now, your friend isn't going to leave you now, if there are still months to have. So, she has time to think this through sensibly.  You are brilliant for trying to provide options for her, and to present those to her. But then you also have to step back and allow what development takes shape. Things will fall into place as and when they are right. And at the moment it seems to me that an ideal solution has as yet not been found.  Something will haven when it is really really important!  The boyfriend may appear stubborn, but then maybe he is reluctant to just make decisions on the run! I can understand that, especially if he has a job, and he has a home. Yes, he loves her, but his priorities are not necessarily to see himself move closer to her family, when he might feel he is more able to look after her just exactly where they are now.  Apart from moving, there is also the option to just keep commuting, both her, whilst she is able, and her family, if they feel as strongly as she does that they want to be near her.  I don't know whether maybe she hasn't shared her sense of urgency with her family, because she doesn't want to worry them. And you are quite right, that it is not your place to do so. But if that was the case, then trying to gently nudge her to more fully communicate with her lot, would actually benefit both parties. Because then everyone is on the same sheet!  You are truly a very good friend. But you cannot do it for her. She has to make the decisions herself. And I think you have to allow her the time to be frightened, and to come to the right decisions in her own time. If that ultimately means she moves without the boyfriend, then so be it. If it means she doesn't move, then I would suggest that was in the end more important to her.  I wonder, do you have a Maggie's centre near you? Or another similar drop-in, where there are people, who can help you and your friend, just by listening, to come to a more peaceful frame of mind. Ultimately, that is what you are trying to achieve for the two of you!  I am glad you have found us here, and please feel free to keep communicating here. It is hopefully going to be useful for yourself to just get your thoughts straight, and to maybe stop that initial panic.  Hugs,  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: months to live. secondary cancer breast

Posts.Content: hey Ceri, Oh, I do feel for you. I have just been to my first 'annual' mammogram - it is well past a year for me.  And even though my objective part of my brain was telling me, don't be silly, this is just routine, there is nothing untoward, the reality was that I was shitting myself as I was sat outside the ominous office.  The problem is that the not-so-objective part of our brain recollects all the steps and stages from the one previous experience which so unsettled us! We prepare ourselves for the worst case scenario, and make the comparison with what we already experienced. I don't know about you, I had found my lump myself. So I was aware that there was something when I presented in Mai of last year. Having quite small boobs I feel I am maybe in a better position to find something, and that kind of helped me as I turned up for my mammogram this time. I had not felt a lump this time round! On top of that I am swimming with Herceptin still and I am rattling with Tamoxifen. So, come on ... what chance realistically could there be that those blighters are still kicking around?!  And yet, there I was, sat waiting for my appointment, really really needing to know that there is nothing on the scan!  I have been told it gets easier! And in a way, I have already started to experience that. It is a case of learning to trust that you have a life and a future again. Learning to trust that you feel comfortable with your changed healthy body. - But I think there may always be certain events which bring the fear right back to us, just because of the trauma that was caused with our first diagnosis.  Maybe my advice is, be aware, that the worry and angst you experience is in part a re-living of the events a year ago. You are in the best hands, and you have had the treatment. And from now on, if there is a recurrence, they will find it really early!  Good luck, and let us know of the results. Don't envy you for the squishing experience though!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: 12 month check up - scared !

Posts.Content: hey Genorm, My oncologist didn't send me for my first annual mammogram until about a year and a half since first diagnosis. I do know he was worried about all the radiation exposure I was having to deal with, and I think he felt he wanted to make the spacing as long as he could.  Once it was decided though to have the mammogram it didn't take long for the appointment to come through.  And yes, it is the oncologist who appears to make a referral back to the surgeon, and it is then the surgeon who refers to the mammogram. Complicated, isn't it?!  Hope this doesn't confuse you even more, I would just keep on asking, right until you get!  Dorothee
Posts.Title: 12 month check up - scared !

Posts.Content: Hey Anne, SAME! I have never had indigestion before, and thankfully never again since!  But I would wake up with those in the early hours of the morning. I think it's to do with the lying position. Sitting up or getting up helps. And I have had arrowroot biscuits next to my bed, and I nibbled on one of those, which seemed to settle things back down!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Strange sensation

Posts.Content: Hey Orangetulip, 'How do you do it?' - the question, I think is: how do YOU do this in the best possible way for yourself!  You sound totally overwhelmed by all that has happened, and by the prospect of all that is yet to come. A complete overload of information, feelings, attitudes, suggestions, well-meaning advice.  At this point I think what I would need to do first of all is go into a soundproof room and scream! And shout! - And as I have suggested before: throw some plates!  And then, start again. But one step at a time! One decision at a time, one concept at a time!  Maybe, whilst you are in your sound-proof room, have a little listen to yourself: what is it that I need to know just now? What is it I want first and foremost just now?  And take it from there!  Trust me, you don't need a wig just now! Not unless YOU feel you do! Apart from that, I have not used wigs myself, I have gone with scarves and beanie hats.  And TRYING to stay positive doesn't cut it for me either! because by trying so hard, you might miss the fact that actually you have all sorts of emotions which you are not letting to the surface! You may well want to be positive, but you have to make room for it! And so, I don't think there is anything wrong with acknowledging all the other feelings and emotions you have just now: fear, anger, loss, frustration! Give them some attention too - maybe more plates are needed, and the soundproof room is needing reinforcing!  Seriously, one step at a time! And you prioritise on YOUR terms! And that might just mean putting the kettle on first of all, and having a soak in the bath!  Big hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: FEC, Taxotere then Letrozole how do you do this?

Posts.Content: Good morning April, I wonder whether you have tried the citizen advice bureau? And maybe speaking to one of the Macmillan nurses here on the free phone line might bring you a bit more clarity on options for your friend.  But I am also wondering whether you yourself are getting enough support here! It might be useful for you to link into the Family And Friends group. There you can openly discuss with other carers what options and what frustrations you have.  Your friend is very fortunate to have you there beside her. It is great when someone can do the leg work when you feel all rotten. So well done you. - However, you are likely to have problems, because of your friend's independence, but also because you are not considered family. And unless you are really close with her family, I am not sure you are in the loop of what is being discussed among them. If she feels she needs to be close to them, and they feel the same way, then it is up to them to sort out her living arrangements.  I would also be a little cautious on the notion of 'months to live'. How long is a piece of string?? How do we know how long anyone does along the road of treatments. She may surprise you all, and really have a shot at the treatments still available to her. I have friends who have been diagnosed with 'terminal cancer', and they are still kicking the boot at the dreaded disease!! Not going anywhere yet!  Committing to taking in your friend, into your home is very commendable. But it is also very very hard! And you have no idea how long you have invited her in for!  I do hope you and your friend find a way through this maze.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: months to live. secondary cancer breast

Posts.Content: hey Annie, A chest infection and ulcers on the breast ... that's a cocktail on it's own for making you feel soooo run down. When your body caries all these toxins they don't tend to stop outside the brain.  I guess with the Tax your body is not really able to heal itself yet either. As all the brand new cells are being destroyed that would include any cells which would just want to do the general maintenance and skin repair. This leaves you with wounds which struggle to heal.  They really do take you to the very edge! Hang on in there honey! A lot of what you are going through has purpose!  And if staying in bed is all you can manage for now, then stay in bed!  Sending strength and warmth Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: had my 3rd tax and blood transfusion

Posts.Content: hey Annie, Was thinking about you too, as I am still loitering around the 'tanning studio' every morning. And Eider, love your sense of humour amongst the misery of fluid retention in the wrong area!!!  I am thinking of you both and send you warm glows! I must be visible at night by now ... I'll put my name in for 'the Ghost of Christmas Past' and go haunting ... lol.  Lots of love as ever to all you strugglers. Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: had my 3rd tax and blood transfusion

Posts.Content: Good job there G&J.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Abbreviations

Posts.Content: I suppose bottom line is to do what your mum and her doctor think is the best for HER.  If she has an underlying heart condition, then maybe that is something to consider. But then, having a mastectomy is a much bigger op than a lumpectomy, and there are more risks in that too. My lumpectomy was on my left breast as well, and I am about to undertake 4 weeks of rads. And my breasts aren't terribly big either, so, not much padding ;) . But I trust that my heart is just going to cope with what I am giving it to handle. And I will take the hint of taking it easy, and taking the rest.  If you and your mum trust the oncologist, then I think, go with that. The journey your mum is going to take is not an easy one, whichever choices she makes. So, be there for her and support her, as you are doing! It is so important to know people are rooting for you when the going gets tough.  Thinking of you both, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Lumpectomy and radiation or mastectomy?

Posts.Content: hey Flower, you sound to me like you are not coping with the lack of control in your life just now! I can relate to that.  It's like we think we have been holding all the threads which make our lives tick. We are so busy organising, we anticipate so as to reduce damage before it happens. We are masters of damage control, after all! And then, bang, things are happening where there doesn't appear to be a thread to hold. Stuff happens, out of control.  Your lack of sleep, I think, may be your mind's unconscious efforts to be claiming back some control: you may be missing something, you are letting go - and you cannot afford to do that.  And yet, I think, in the end, it was the complete handing over of the control to the medics, which saved my sanity!  Like you, I feel I am one of the very lucky ones here: I had the lumpectomy last May and have had all the bootcamp and tanning, am still doing tablets and Herceptin. But: I am here!! And ticking over nicely!  It takes time to feel the trust in your life again, in finding those threads again, which in all the panic you dropped, and you will find new threads to pick up and enjoy!  As for the thread which is called cancer treatment: leave that one for your oncologist and your nurses to carry! Let others share your balancing act of control. Let them make decisions of how to move forward with your treatment, and TRUST you are doing what feels right!  And then, with a hot bubble bath, a glass of bubbly, candles - celebrate! you have got so far through this hell-hole! you deserve to sit back, pat yourself on your back! You are doing well!  And then maybe, just maybe, you can trust yourself to get a good night sleep again! Sleep, after all, is healing! Your body and your mind need healing. Let your sleep do the mending for you! Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Feeling Guilty Now

Posts.Content: Awwwe! This appears to be turning into a group hug, or team huddle! I think we all need and deserve to be part of that one!!!! - Sorry, gate crashing the party! lol  I think we are all A-ma-zing! This is a journey none of us has wanted, but we are holding our heads up high through this boot-camp and coming out the other end!!!  I would particularly like to include in this huddle all of you, who are struggling to hold onto that rope at the moment - KEEP HOLDING ON!!! Keep reaching out for helping hands, they are there!  I am pioneering along the sun bed sessions just now, didn't think I would celebrate Christmas with the last of these ... But, going with a glow right over my heart now (left breast is being zapped!)  Lots of love to you all Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Shout out to Sassy and all the amazing lovely ladies on here!

Posts.Content: I used Facebook as well. Initially totally by coincidence: my daughter had set me and herself a challenge for the year 2012. And I accepted it!: Project 365 - or as it was a leap year, it turned out to be Project 366.  You take a photograph every single day of the year, and keep a picture diary of your personal year that way. - Little did I know in January what was going to happen through the year. I found my lump in April, had my op in May, started Bootcamp in June etc.  I posted my pictures as I saw them on the day, each day, with a little caption, a comment of relevance. That way I shared with friends, who were and are important to me. It stopped stupid questions at times, because I could say 'had a shitty day', or it was obvious by what was going on. It also really took away the taboo from the ominous cancer . I knew people knew, and so conversation didn't have to get started on 'how are you'.  In the main though it was a beautiful collection of really lovely memories of the year. I made a picture book of a selection of the pictures at the end of the year and gave it my husband for his Christmas present. Looking through it now, I can honestly say, I have had another amazing year - despite everything! The wonderful things I experienced totally outweigh Bootcamp and Tanning, but make it all so much worth it!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: What do i say? Odd question i know....

Posts.Content: I think there is another factor here hiding underneath the obvious. I think with our diagnosis comes a new sense of relevance! We are much more atune to what is important and what is waffle. and we don't have time for rubbish, because life is too precious!  People always make stupid, unnecessary conversation - worst one is at my Asda check-out, when the lady ask "so, how are you today?" - My thoughts are always "now, where do I begin ..."  And then you get people who really do care, but they are more worried about their own feelings, and really want you to feel sorry for them, because they are so worried about YOU!  There is a kind of helplessness in there. Not knowing what to say or what to do. - I told my mum off for asking me how I was every other day! I was honest and brutal! But I needed to get the question out of the way from her. On a bad day I didn't want to be asked, and on a good day I didn't feel I wanted to be bothered.  The question of 'how are you' actually becomes incredibly sensitive and meaningful, and it throws us into the 'cancer victim' situation! That's where we belong, that's our destitute, and that's all we can now talk about and live with. That question removes the fact that I am still me, I am still interested in other things, I am still quite capable of holding a normal conversation!  The question brings to the fore the fact that we have changed, and we are working on a new alignment! We are working with new rules in our lives. And it is something both we and our environment have to get used to.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: What do i say? Odd question i know....

Posts.Content: Hey guys,  did you know Macmillan give financial advice and support! Highlight the link, and see if you can get in touch. They have people who are very good at this!  Good luck,  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: No financial help!!

Posts.Content: Hey guys,  did you know Macmillan give financial advice and support! Highlight the link, and see if you can get in touch. They have people who are very good at this!  Good luck,  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: No financial help!!

Posts.Content: Oh dear! I couldn't do it to myself! Wasn't brave enough. You can indeed get your district nurse to do it for you! Or, if you have a partner, or a close friend, then you may ask them to do it for you instead.  It might just be the case that the first one is the hardest, and then you may think 'don't know what all the fuss was about'. But, as I say, I chickened! Was really not happy to stab myself.  Good luck, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Self injections for 7 days

Posts.Content: keep holding onto what the chemo nurse was telling you: there are more treatments out there!!!! And you are embarking on one right now!!!  The first chemo DID work initially, it was just not strong enough to cope for long!  Tough road ahead, BUT there IS a road ahead, and there are people going with you all the way!!  You are so brave, deep breath in, and this thing IS going to get beaten!! Right from tomorrow!!!  Lots of love Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Not great scan results :(

Posts.Content: hey Becky, what a wonderful, caring granddaughter you are!  And your nan sounds to be in good hands!  As we are not medically trained, I think it would be very wrong for us here to guess at the reason for your nan's tummy upset, and pain. However, the GP IS the right person, and so is your nan's oncologist!  I too would suggest you offer to go along with your nan to the GP on Wednesday. Two people are a lot better organised and focussed for asking all the relevant questions, and you can maybe write things down for her, so she can discuss the results with you after.  Today is only the 3rd, so you still have 10 days to settle her and make sure things are ticking over, before you leave. And maybe, if she has a good friend, or a close neighbour, who might be willing and able to see in on her whilst you are away, the that would give you and her peace of mind, and you can enjoy your deserved break!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Calcichews and tummy trouble?

Posts.Content: Hi Helen, your lymph system around your foot and leg should not be affected by the fact that you have had lymph nodes removes from your axilla.  However, if it is getting inflamed, then it may have been a 'dirty' bite. As in the mossi might have carried something, which is causing your inflammation. So, if it doesn't get better, or if it gets worse then a trip to the pharmacist might be a good idea. There are creams, which you can apply to make sure you get the area cleaned up!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Mossi bite help needed

Posts.Content: hey Mulheron,  just wanting to wish you good luck for your appointment tomorrow.  You found a change, and it worries you. So you are right to check it out. There is no amount of goggling though which will ease your mind, until your doctors have had a good look at it. so, I would go and leave the google sites to themselves.  Please let us know how you get on tomorrow. And if there is any bad News, well then you have all our support here.  Good luck,  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Nipple change

Posts.Content: Hey guys,  I must admit, I agree with Katharine on this one! With a known history, I would be have wanted nothing but a referral!  I would call back and arrange to either see another GP, or to get yours to give you a referral.  Remember, you can also ring the nurses here on the helpline, and ask them for their advice! Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Nipple change

Posts.Content: Good luck with your tanning, girls. If you have done chemo, then you will find this a doddle.  Love the idea of putting the cream into the fridge. That makes a heap of sense, just got to remember not to plaster the cream on in the kitchen, with young adult males co-occupying ... I am an embarrassment, I keep being told. lol  Being worried when it comes to the end of our prescribed treatment I think is only to be expected. Suddenly we are left to our own devices again, and yet, normal is just not normal.  It's like learning to walk all over again. I am taking first steps, and I am so unsure about so much. Slotting back into the routines as if nothing has happened is just not realistic. I think it will take time to find that confidence again that things are okay.  I have just booked flights for May to visit family, and I have been nervous even to do that, because so much can happen ... - Or better: so much did happen last year at that time. Last year I had booked a similar flight, then found my lump in April, and then everything went pear shaped.  Maybe, if we have done a year of no issues, then the confidence may come back and settle us into our new lives.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Last hurdle!!!!!

Posts.Content: hey Dawn, you sound very scared, Panic driven, in your contemplations.  This diagnosis is very, very fresh to you. And you have not had any time at all to even scratch the surface of coming to terms with it. On top of that, it sounds to me you are still mourning the loss of your mum. And having lost her to cancer brings back all the memories now, and you are faced with all her angst again now.  I can see your thinking. you need the thing out, and you need to take precaution that it doesn't return.  Okay, so far so good.  Things to consider:  are there guarantees that you are taking the best option? NO! So, you have to come to a decision of what feels best for you just now. And making that decision with as much information as you can get, is probably a wise move.  Right, point of least side effects: I am not sure here, but I believe a double mastectomy is Hugely invasive on your body! It will take a while to get over such an op. And the risks are there as well, with anaesthetic, inflamation of wounds. And straight forward compromised mobility.  Side effects from rads, in comparison, is tiredness. And rib pain possibly.  Side effects of tablets, well, that depends on the individual. personally, I have been fine so far. Having done Tamoxifen and Herceptin now for a year. I can honestly say, it is not holding me back. And I have the reassurance that my body is still trying to protect itself.  Your grade one tumour really is very small. And if your medical team is happy that they have removed it all, then why not trust them in their prognosis for you. It is the least invasive option.  I hope you will be able to make an informed choice. It's tough, and very scary for you right now. But they have found it early, and treatments are in general very successful these days.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Lumptectomy vs Bilateral Mastectomy HELP ME PLEASE!

Posts.Content: well done indeed!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Nipple change

Posts.Content: hey Dawn, you have some good reasons to be nervous about certain aspects. I would suggest you write your worries down, and take that list to your surgeon and your BC nurse. They, in turn, need to address those worries, and give you their information on each. In the end it is your decision, and I am sure they will say that to you, too. But, make sure you are not just running away from your fears, into aspects of treatment, which may have their own issues.  Good luck, maybe take your partner, or a good friend with you. Two eyes and ears often cope better than just one when you are feeling so overwhelmed.  Hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Lumptectomy vs Bilateral Mastectomy HELP ME PLEASE!

Posts.Content: hey Friz,  yeah, I think my arm is just about fully recovered now. - I finished my last bootcamp session in October of last year. So, a year on, and yes, the arm is fully functional again, and the visible line has gone as well. I have had a year of Herceptin as well, and although the nurses struggled with the veins, it didn't get any worse! I had 6 FEC, and after the last one the arm was very tight indeed. It gets worse with each go.  As I said, my nurse pushed the FEC in real slowly to try and cause as little damage as poss, and then she flushed the vein after.  Apparently applying heat may help as well to get the veins to recover - but don't scold yourself! lol  Good luck,  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Arm pain after chemo drugs

Posts.Content: Hey guys,  I am getting quite good at this referencing malarky. ;)  Here is the info on Tamoxifen from Macland.  If you want to have a read through the Breast Cancer booklet, that is very informative, and also has a sec ion on Tamoxifen. And yes, it may well stop your periods and put you into a menopausal state.  Mine stopped going through FEC, and I am glad to the the back of it. - There has to be some positives to take away with me?! And nearly 2 years down the line now I haven't got any periods. I do however have an increase in discharge, which means I am kitting out with pantiliners. It's all doable though. Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Periods returning

Posts.Content: Hey Ethel,  I did my tanning up until Christmas and had a couple of dubious days weather wise. I called the 'tanning studio' and the nurses were lovely and said just get there when you can. So, I just took it gently and arrived late.  But if you are stressing about going in the first place because weather is bad, then my advise would be: stay safe! No point trying to kill yourself on the roads - yes, the pun is intended! ;)  Keep safe!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: What if I can't get to the hospital because of the snow for rads?

Posts.Content: I finished 18 tanning sessions two weeks ago. I creamed up with aqueous cream morning and night. I did not use any products under the shower. I did not wear a bra (I do get away with that anyway, never had more than a handful lol). Light cotton t-shirts directly on your skin.  My skin is read, and the ribs around the scar area feel bruised. But it is easing now.  Good luck. Your tanning is the least worrying treatment. The travelling gets tedious.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Last hurdle!!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Friz,  I am wondering whether you are experiencing 'cording'. - In effect, your veins tighten up, and you feel you can't stretch as you used to, and you may well see your veins, like a line going up your lower arm.  Yes, that would be a side-effect. And the only consolation really is, that the veins will try and recover once you have finished with your bootcamp.  In the meantime, I think it massively helps to know what it is. And to know that other people get the same issue.  STRETCHING helps! I used the arm to reach for mugs in the cupboards, and plates etc. And I got the physio to show me stretch moves, which would be gentle, but would work towards getting the arm more mobile again, or keeping it as mobile as possible.  You may want to ask at your next chemo to have it run through a little slower, and make sure that they definitely run the saline through after you have had the chemo, in order to flush the veins as much as you can.  Having said all that, I would mention it at your next appointment with the medics. let them know you are in pain. Don't just assume! It's always best to have things checked out properly.  Hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Arm pain after chemo drugs

Posts.Content: well said, Sue.  I think our acquaintance with Annabel has brought everything home that we hold dear and which we so fear to lose. And as brave as we may all be, and as hopeful and passionate to be doing the right thing or the best thing to hold the cancer away, it is a sudden jerk to reality that we are unfortunately not invincible. And sometimes, nothing we do is ever going to make the slightest bit of a difference.  I believe it was Annie's time. It's as straight forward as that. We can't choose when we come into this world and we can't choose when we have to depart - the difference is, on departing, we have memories and hopes and anticipation - the luxury of consciousness.  Consciousness is the trade off for our beautiful lives. It makes it hard, but it is central to who we are. Because of Annabel's brave struggle and the way her family are so admirably trying to cope, I feel myself in a better place for addressing my own fears. I am grateful for her sharing, and I embrace the inevitability with more of an open eye. The difference is not in WHEN do I have to leave this beautiful place, but HOW am I going to spend the time I am still given. Lots of love to you all out there Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Feels empty here

Posts.Content: hey,  I am wondering about your terminology of your two lumps:  the medics refer to both 'grade' and 'stage'. Both mean different things.  Your grade of tumour is the type of aggressiveness.  Your stage as to do with size and spread.  I am not trying to be pedantic here, just trying to see if I can get some more insight for yourself in why sounds like all new and very scary info!  The grading of your tumours are being done with the help of your biopsies. And if they are both from the same root, then I would think they are probably the same grading.  Now, grading really is just something for the medical team to worry about, I think. It determines for them what kind of treatment they ail be giving you.  Mine was graded as 3, which was pretty nasty, but then it was all hormone positive, and with that they have had lots of angles to go shoot the bugger down!  Stage, as I say, has to do with size and spread. Again, it really is medics terminology to categorise what they are dealing with.  Stage 2 starts at 2cm in size. There is nothing more to it than that.    My guess is, but please correct me if I am wrong, that what you have been given are stages, rather than grades. One lump being smaller than the other, and the possibility of localised spread.  I hope this bit of info helps a little. It's not meant to frighten you. It's meant to take the fear of the unknown a little.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Diagnosed on Thursday

Posts.Content: Hi Rebecca, Can I offer a set of plates? They smash exceptionally well on concrete! Go for it, have it out! It's shite! I suspect every now and again, for whatever reason, it is tangible to us what we are paying for. And it's not a one off payment, it comes in installments! And with tax on top! Remember Sassy calling us upgrades? - it's like early versions of Ironman! Things are not thought through, and adjustments cannot always be made in time. And we crash land! But then, what would the alternative be? So long as there is no comparison, we will just have to pick ourselves back up from those crash landings. Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Is cancer not enough?!

Posts.Content: Hey Annie, When I was reading your distress I found myself remembering what we had been told after childbirth: rest whenever you can - leave the housework be, and time yourself with the rhythm of the child.  Just go with the essentials! And then I agree, yoga or pilates is a really good idea - you may find a yoga teacher who would probably be quite happy to visit you and give you some guidance. Sports clubs have them and they also make use in community halls or church halls.  I was wondering about reflexology, too. Anyone else any idea whether that may over stimulate the body at this point? I have had my 'chat' with the one this evening. So, will be starting the chemo back end of next week. - How is your hair doing, Annie? At what point am I going to loose it?  Stay strong, it's all for a good cause!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Complementary therapies/relaxtion

Posts.Content: Hi Annie, Yeah, tick on feeling queazy! Have already dipped into the antiemetic box, lol, and I am just 'enjoying' a couple of arrowroot biscuits. That fine line, where you feel sick if you think of food, but actually if you eat something, it will make you feel better, because an empty stomach doesn't help, either.  Yeah, funny we are now on the same day, but remember, you were a week ahead when we started and a whole round ahead. You've still got the week on me, but because I did luxury holiday in hospital for 5 days, I have moved onto your time schedule, one week later.  Still thinking of how short changed you feel just now! I cannot believe that! - I am sat frustrated for you!!! Can you go back to your GP? Have you already? Can they find you a better oncologist and Can you go private - on the counselling? I know such a lovely counselling lady up here in Scotland, do you think she might have connections to where you are? (I don't know where you are, ooops) I would easy try and have a shot, see what I can do. Let me know. Back to my arrowroot biscuits - oh and flat coke! Oh the luxuries!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: horrible onc appt, horrible news

Posts.Content: Hey Robs, Great to hear the op went okay.  I imagine your hypersensitivity may have a couple or so reasons: firstly, you have had nerve ending interfered with. And as your bruising is coming out and the swelling from the op is calming down, so the battered and tingled nerves come out to play for a while.  I must admit, the nerves around my affected breast have had a battering, and I get strange sensations of numbness, like when you get back from the dentist. And in the first place it really felt a bit like the nerves were waking up again. It will all calm down, I am certain.  But the other thing is, I am also quite sure you are more aware of what's going on in your affected breast. And just that hyper awareness may make you feel more sensitive. - Welcome to the club of hypochondriacs! This is your initiation ceremony!  You may well find that you worry now about all sorts of feelings, bumps, or bumps which aren't even there. It is a case of learning to trust your body again, and that does take time. Also, certainly for myself, I used to take it for granted that both sides would be the same! And that was how I discovered my lump in the first place - it was different.  You may now start to feel all sorts of differences between your two boobies, especially if you go down the route of radiotherapy. It is a case of learning from scratch your new body image again.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Post surgery sensitivity

Posts.Content: hey swan, I wouldn't so much call it a 'phase' as a 'trauma'. And your mind is bruised as much as your body is! My heart goes out out to you, and I would love to just give you a great big hug and let you know you are so not alone!  This is tough, and I think it is even tougher when you have done it all once before. You need to give yourself time to absorb it all. Feeling strong isn't all about keeping things in, either. Feeling strong, I think also means knowing when it's time to let go, time to have a howl, or a blubber.  It's shit, and you are just as well to call it that. But you also know you have done it once before, and things move on all the time! So there is every reason to be positive. Maybe looking at it as an isolated incident puts another angle to the perspective. Rather than saying: it's back. Say: it's a separate one. And as you now have had a mastectomy you have shown the c-cells where to get off! Also consider that maybe the change in your state of hormones is now changing, and possibly making you feel less like yourself. Tamoxifen has a lot to answer for! :)  I am wondering, how would you feel about some pampering? Get the duvet out onto the sofa and watch movies, find those naughty chocolates, have a candle lit bubble bath. - And celebrate the fact that you are doing awesome! You have just thrown out the big baddy for the second time round! And you are doing really well!  Hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: back again @37

Posts.Content: never mind cry me a river - in your house it's cry me a bathtub! lol oh the joys of parenthood, when you are feeling like you want to curl up in a ball! But I am sure they will also give you lots of inspiration, lots of love and so many reasons to face this battle hands down!  My kiddies are all that little bit older. Youngest now is 20, so was just turning 19 when we got the News last year in May. It's never easy, I don't know whether you have spoken with yours about what is happening. I decided to lay all the cards on the table and then work through the mess with them! And they have been a fantastic support system for me - most probably, because I could be totally brutally honest with them. But as I say, they were a few years ahead.  I think crying that bathtub full is probably a very good option! Letting those emotions flow makes space for emotions which are going to be much more practical for you! Getting some of that fighting spirit back, telling the c-cells to piss off, alongside the bathwater down the drain!  Positive thinking is so helpful, so important. But there has to be room for it. And when you carry a heavy load of worries and fears, then there just isn't any room left!  Yeah, I would be happy to pm you, see if you can find me.  Can I also maybe suggest 'Annabel's Angels' to you, if you are on Facebook! We are a lovely bunch of ladies, and some gents, who have come together over the past year or so, on the back of finding each other here on Macland. We are now a little organisation, trying to support people like ourselves online and out there in the community. So, if you'd like to chat via fb, see if you find us. :)
Posts.Title: back again @37

Posts.Content: hey Annie, LOve the thought of a new car!!!!! What did you get?  Maybe I'm running against your grain here, but the one thought that jumps out for me is a very defiant: WHY NOT surgery???? Don't take it sitting down! I'd want to have that beast removed whatever! As others have said, you are young! So, I don't see here that you couldn't take an op and recover well from it.  I would ask, if the mets in the lung shrink enough, so you can deal with a break in the chemo, then, why the hell not remove the shite in the breast. Can't keep spreading when it's out of the darned way!  But in order to ask that, you need to see someone you TRUST! I'd love to give you my very lovely oncologist. He is to die for sweet and caring. That's what you need!!!!!!  Sending you lots of hugs and energy Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: horrible onc appt, horrible news

Posts.Content: Annie, please don't be sorry for feeling how you do! Don't be brave, just let it out. And let people around you know as well how you feel! Might just make the appointment for your counselling a little more urgent!!! If you hide yourself away, and you are successful at putting up that front, then that's not going to help you get what you need now!  Hope chemo is going okay - I am with you on the trepidation! My 2nd one has now been delivered this morning. So here is hoping for a stay at home this time round. As much as I appreciated the little vacation during round 1.  Thinking of you, sending energy so you may cope the best way YOU WANT to cope. You are amazing! Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: horrible onc appt, horrible news

Posts.Content: Please make extra space for me in that suitcase to Turkey!!  We are thinking of booking Turkey, too. I discovered waterskiing in 2011 - I am determined to have another shot at that. Got to get some upper body strength though - don't know how the muscles would cope just now. First trip for me this year is with my lovely daughter. We are having a long weekend in Dublin in January, with Ed Sheeran concert, and loads of shopping.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: new year onwards and upwards

Posts.Content: Good morning pennyred, You are absolutely in the right place here to have a good moan!  I called the chemo 'experience' Bootcamp! And bootcamp has just started for you. Pains everywhere, ulcers, headaches and hair everywhere except on your head ... yeah, there are some good reasons to feel sorry for yourself and have a good moan, and a good cry!!!  Trying to figure what is causing what is pretty difficult too. But I think the advice of reading your body temp is a good one. When the temperature is normal, then you are okay!  As you are loosing hair so incredibly badly - or rather well?! - Have you considered making an appointment with your lovely hairdresser, and having a No1? It makes the loss a little more bearable, I think, as you just have to deal with it the once in one go. And part of your headache problem is that the roots of your hair are being pulled by the weight of the hair, and that's causing the nerves in your scalp to play havoc!  I am very much a supporter of having a good cry, when you feel like it! No shame in that, and the body kind of does self help, in that you will feel better after! And it clears your head to make space again for coping with the onslaught!  I am also a great supporter of smashing crockery! - Retail therapy is useful anyway!! There are times when life does get frustrating, and we are so not in control of anything, and we just have to sit and bear it! It's not really called 'moaning', it's called coping with bootcamp!!!  Hugs,  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Sore mouth,sore scalp, sorely in need of advice, please!

Posts.Content: Happy New Year, to you too. I have left bootcamp (chemo) and tanning studio (radiotherapy) in the old year. Looking forward to new things to come.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: new year onwards and upwards

Posts.Content: hey Cathy,  Stitches usually take 10 days to heal I believe. So if you are over a week now and you really feel like having a bath, then I would do just that! Wouldn't put anything other than maybe some salt into the water though. And I wouldn't soak for too long! Or maybe have a shower instead.  But, I reckon, go for it. Your body soon tells you! Enjoy a good soak. You deserve it!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: post op mastectomy dressing

Posts.Content: Congratulations for getting through your ordeal, both of you. There is a lot of recovering going to have to happen. Unfortunately, I cannot give you an answer to your question. However, I imagine your wife is going to be quite ginger all around her body for a little while. And it seems to be going well, when her doctors are pleased with her progress.  I would still go back to them though, try and find out where the pain stems from, but also to be getting the right painkillers to make your wife more comfortable.  I would imagine she would be encouraged to move around and get mobile, but if she has pains in her feet, then she is restricting herself.  Just keep pestering, that's what your doctors are there for. - Good luck and all the best to both of you.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Pain after surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Mccaan, Interesting concept 'chemopause'! I like that!  Seriously though, interesting question as well. I believe people have gone back to having periods after chemo, so there is definitely room for 'normality' returning.  Myself, I have not had any, I get the odd spots, but nothing like a proper period. But then I am 49 now. So, I suspect 10 years ago I would not be imagining myself to be going through menopause naturally. So, I am thinking nature may very well be wanting a piece of it again!  I would certainly monitor it, maybe mark the date in your diary, and see what happens. And if you are concerned, then pop down to the doctor and have it checked out!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Chemopause yes or no?

Posts.Content: that's a bit worrying .... I hadn't thought of my poor veins! I s it necessarily the case that after chemo and with Herceptin I end up with shot veins???? Are there different veins they can use to relieve the issue of targeting the same one all the time?  And how long, big is the Herceptin IV? How mch needs to be infused at a time???  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Sore good arm

Posts.Content: Big well done! Another graduation! That's bootcamp completed!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Last chemo tomorrow!

Posts.Content: Good morning millan68, I hope your morning is already looking a little better again! It's amazing what a good night's sleep can do - if you are getting one of those.  I reckon after the op and all your treatment your body and your mind just cry out for recovery. after all, we never wanted to be there in the first place, did we?! So your focus is now set on healing! On getting better - but with very little resilience left, as all your energy has been sapped!  In the big picture, this infection really is only a minor set-back, which will hopefully be dealt with quite swiftly with the antibiotics you are now on.  In the meantime, remember, take it easy. Give your body and your mind that space and time to recover slowly. Treat yourself to some 'me'-time, and maybe have a look whether your local cancer drop-in does any form of complementary therapy, which may encourage that healing process both physically and emotionally.  Hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Skin infection 10 days after reconstruction...any advise?

Posts.Content: oh, that SUCKS BIG TIME!  It must be so so difficult to keep standing back up again when you have been getting a pouch in the stomach like that. So cool that you have had the courage and nerve to keep going back for the answers nobody wants to get!  But it appears to me you have been finding your cancers whilst they have been really small, so you have been kind of on top of things! And so you are giving yourself all the chance in the world to get this bugger snuffed out of your system for good.  It is every mum's nightmare, isn't it, to have to unsettle their innocent young lives. But, kids can be quite resilient. No, it won't just pass by them either, and they will have their own way of coping. But I am sure with a loving mum like yourself, they have every opportunity to be loved and cared for.  I would think talking with them must be a good way forward - and maybe not just yourself talking with them, but another close friend or family member. Someone who can help you help them!  And we are all here, to try and help you along with your next steps back into that rink!  I also do hugs!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: 2nd recurrence in 2 years.

Posts.Content: Thinking of you!  Are you taking someone with you? Always good to have a second set of ears and another brain along. There is so much to take in. Take along a list of questions, make notes. And don't hold back on asking, when you don't understand.  Good luck for today. Hope all goes well enough for you. Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Move in the right direction

Posts.Content: Oh dear, you do sound like you are in the wars!  Well done for having got through the op though! Big pat on your back for having conquered the first mountain!  I believe duvet days are in order now! And maybe a glass of wine or two! Watch some rubbish on the telly and have a good cry, if you feel like it too! You have had such an emotional standstill, and now you get the release in form of physical discomfort and pain!  Time for tlc. And maybe find out about those big pillows which people use, to get your arm in a comfy position. And take all the painkillers you are given. No need to be 'strong'!  Big hugs,  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Feeling rough at minute

Posts.Content: I would ask. I remember that I wasn't to take any painkillers with FEC. I am not sure whether there is a possibility of the meds interfering or whether they may be masking a problem, which the docs need to be aware of. As for example a rising temp may be a sign of neutropenia, and taking paracetamol would not be the right thing to take for that.  I would definitely check this one out.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Doxetaxel and codiene

Posts.Content: I have had nose bleeds as the hair dropped out. The skin inside your nose changes, and it becomes really sensitive, like baby skin.  The bleeding stops again when everything settles. Just don't use any of the nose unblocking meds - they sting to the moon and back!!!!!! I also had bleeds again as the hair started to grow back again! So, all normal.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Nose bleeds while having chemo

Posts.Content: Hey Annie, Thinking of you lots! It WILL get better!!!  Was thinking arrowroot biscuits! And charcoal tablets! Both are meant to be useful against sickness, when you have a tummy bug - I know this doesn't quite apply.  Drinking loads to flush the toxins out - but that's easier said than done when you feel sick drinking. I used to give my kids 'flat' coke to drink when they were poorly - It gives you the sugar for a little energy, plenty fluid and all the minerals your body needs. but make sure you drink it flat - shake or stir with a fork, got get the gas out first.  Have you been able to sit outside a little for some fresh air? - All these good ideas ... won't be so full of them when it's my turn in a couple of weeks, I'm sure.  Lots of hugs Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Day 4 after FEC-still green around the gills

Posts.Content: interesting.  I have loads of freckles and moles as well, and I remember growing up with my mum saying: don't sun-bathe! don't use a sun-bed! check out your moles! you can get skin-cancer!  I was careful sunbathing, I only used the sun-bed to try it out. I kept checking my moles - I hadn't anticipated breast cancer ... Bugger! That went under the radar!  Seriously though. What are we to make of this study? Blame it on the moles? Is it a genetic malfunction? Are we going to worry anyone who has moles into believing they are sat on the verge of getting breast cancer?  Maybe, the correlation, which is what it appears to be in that study, has a third factor: it may be related to the caucasian skin type. I don't know whether breast cancer for example is more prevalent in white folk than in coloured skin people.  I personally suspect my hormone treatment to be the culprit of my cancer. But, I suspect, nobody can tell you for certain what has sparked the cells off to go on a shopping spree for more! There is just the possibility of predisposing factors. We have just got to be careful though, that we are not getting frightened by correlating factors, which may not be causations at all!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Moles

Posts.Content: Hi Sascha, I agree with Annie! Make yourself feel good, get a pampering! And if you have a good hair dresser, I would have thought they can advise you on a product for your colouring, too. I would have thought most good hairdressers have a wide expertise these days. And when you go, she might give you a relaxing head massage as well - so soothing!  I was going to have a chat with my hairdresser, too. Now that I know my chemo is upon me soon. I have short hair anyway, but was wondering about when to have it cut even shorter. I am not going with the cold cap, but I don't want to have the trauma of hair falling out over a period of time either. So, thought I might get some advice on how to minimise my stress levels.  Just starting to get my head around having to wear head scarves for the next few months as well - I am in denial!!!! Oh dear! :(  So, go pamper yourself and feel a million dollars, I'd say! That's got to be the right way!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Hair colour??

Posts.Content: I take it your mum has has MUGA scans? - Chemo and Herceptin put pressure on the heart. Nothing to worry about, because this is monitored, and your mum might then be given tablets to support the heart.  But even if nothing shows up, the heart does work harder to cope with the treatment. And a fainting attack can easily happen, when your mum is feeling tired and washed out.  To make sure mum is fine, and doesn't hurt herself, maybe you can suggest that when she feels faint, to sit down, and put her head down between her knees, and concentrate on breathing.  It may also be a good idea for her to carry with her some digestive biscuits or something similar to nibble on. That should keep the bloodsugar in check. And Drink plenty. - But maybe have a play about with caffeine! that might cause issues, as well as hot flushes! And if she has fainting episodes at particular time s in the day, it might be useful to monitor when that might be. And then report it back to the onc or the GP!  Hot flushes are part and parcel of the Herceptin game, and your mum probably also takes tablets like Tamoxifen. these induce menopause, and the hot flushes are part of that! They do get better, but yeah, it's not much fun. The heat regulator appears to be boycotting the general regard for a happy life!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Hot flushes, light headed and fainting

Posts.Content: Hey orangetulip, Go and 'indulge' in a bit of self pity! There is nothing wrong with that! Open the floodgates and have a scream! - I found it quite therapeutic to throw some china as well! - Followed by retail therapy! Your body has just gone through major surgery! It wasn't just a little nip and a tug! You need time to recover physically, as well as mentally, and emotionally!  From a psychological point of view in your brain, I think, it would like to take time out now, to recover: to process all the new information, to set itself up with new coping strategies. - And then you find you don't seem to have that time, because the run-away train hasn't as yet programmed in a convenient stop!  I agree with Dee, good idea to just take it one step at a time!  And leave the planning and organisation to your medical team! That's what they are good at.  When I entered the world of cancer last year, I found I handed over the controls to my surgeon, my oncologist and my wonderful team of nurses. they tell me what is best for me, and they make the appointments. All I have to do is be there, and COPE!  I believe this process is one of grieving, just as much as we might be suffering some form of post traumatic stress! We are generally not prepared for the news we are being given at point of diagnosis. And we are ill-equipped to handle the effects and changes.  This journey is draining! And it will continue to drain for a while yet. So, again, I agree with Dee: if you can get a support network in place to help you along, that's not being defeatist, it's not being self indulgent - It's sensible precaution.  We are meant to be social animals, and yet we hide in the corner, when we are poorly! In this situation it shows strength and willpower to hold up your hand and say I am not coping here!  Just one step at a time - and you are so not on your own!  Hugs Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: I don't know what to say now

Posts.Content: hey guys,  thanks.  Wow, Herceptin No 15, Sue?!! I have just had No 10! getting there, too! - Seemed such a long way, but, i am getting there, too!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: 14 months later :-))

Posts.Content: If in doubt, check it out!  Having said that, last year, about 6 months on from Bootcamp and tanning, I developed a cough. And I couldn't shift that cough for weeks on end! I have a feeling that we have got more susceptible to catching stuff, and the toasting around the lung area may just have got the bronchi a little more flustered when it comes to shaking off an infection.  But, it's always a good idea to go and have it checked out. Gives you peace of mind at least. Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Coughing

Posts.Content: Sounds like you are on 'maintenance' now! Like myself: Herceptin, Tamoxifen, Perindopril for me. Nice concoction. Very well done for coming this far!  During the 2012 class we had been talking about 'becoming upgrades' of ourselves. I think that is a very good terminology! It throws out the comparison and expectation of what is or used to be 'normal'. And it puts us into a brand new playing field, which we should recognise and work with.  Upgrades: we have changed so much, physically and emotionally and mentally and spiritually since we began climbing the mountain that's cancer.  Maybe comparing it to the climb of a mountain isn't such a bad idea: you climbed up it, with tears and sweat. There wasn't anywhere else to go, as the gorge next to you was just a sheer drop. So, you started to climb, never knowing how long, how far, or what was around the corner.  But you carried on walking, trusting that this was a good enough route to take. Hoping it would get you across to easier grounds. Now you have reached the summit! Yeah. Taken a good look around, and it's all been well worth the climb. How beautiful the world can look! - But now you have just recently started on the way down! Arrrgh, scary, as you notice the gorge is still there right next to you! And you are exhausted from the earlier climb up. Your body hasn't recovered itself yet. If you sat down now, you'd get cramps, and would want to fall asleep. You don't want to walk down any more now, you just want to be back down off the mountain!  Take your time walking on down. You will find it does get easier, as you start trusting yourself again. Give yourself all the rest on the way, you deserve it, your body and your mind need it!  But don't look to walk on the other side of the mountain either! You are now on the side you came down: take a good look round. It appears to be the same, but it so isn't: is the grass always greener on the other side? No, but it's different. And because you have climbed that mountain, you are equipped to take a good look around! There are new challenges, new opportunities, there's a new you! Just make sure you take your time, and keep walking along the path. You have come so far. Don't give up on yourself now!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: 14 months later :-))

Posts.Content: Keeping all fingers and toes very crossed for you, Canton. Please take all our support with you into your scan!  Hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Freaking out slightly

Posts.Content: hello lovely ladies, awe Sue, such a wonderful thread you have started here.  It is so lovely to pop in and find familiar 'faces'. and it is just as wonderful to hear new ones, who are just starting to work it all out for themselves.  I feel so privileged to be in your crowd. And if we can make a difference even to one more worried soul, it would make my day - every day!  As MacMillan have been saying, no-one should be facing cancer on their own. And, ladies, we are in the front seats for making that difference! I am so proud of us!  Let's keep reaching out!  Lots of love Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: 14 months later :-))

Posts.Content: hi NannyMary, Your determination for the next steps shines right through! I am so glad you find some courage from all these people here. It's a tough old road!  But don't get disheartened when your spirits sink - that's also part of the 'experience'! And then, let people around you know, so they can help you along a little.  Sometimes it's enough to just take one step at a time. Don't think you have to stride along! You exhaust yourself just trying!  Hope your appointment today was positive and encouraging.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: feeling very positive

Posts.Content: hey Vanilla,  My response for this question has always been: No Regret! Whatever your decision, it is yours. And the considerations to take along the way relate to your own life, to your priorities, to your ideals, to your way of life.  My question in this position would be: if I didn't take the chemo, if I didn't even try it, how would I feel if I was amongst those 5%?!  On the other hand, if you have reasonable doubts, as to why you think that chemo would not be for you (excluding reasons like it's shit!), your question might be: is the long term quality of my life compromised to the point that you would come to regret the decision to take it.  It is not easy, and it is a very personal choice.  I wonder though how you might feel about discussing this with your partner, and maybe a very close friend of yours.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Chemo or not

Posts.Content: I agree with Mistymoley.  The dye makes for easier reading with regards organs, because that's where the dye is going. I would have thought it makes no difference with regards to examining bones.  CT scans are just better x-rays machines, and so the reading of x-rays is done perfectly well! I am sure your doctor will be fully able to read the results! They are very well trained to do so! And if you cannot take the dye, then it is not a question of: better with or without dye, but rather: better to have the CT scan done than not! Hope you get good results! Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Is a CT scan without contrast dye as effective??

Posts.Content: Hi,  I am so sorry you have had to find yourself here amongst this distinguished lot. It's a good place to be, I believe. There are a to of folk here who know what you are feeling right now.  Mixed up with info sounds about right in the beginning. You feel like a train has hit you. You hadn't seen it coming and it just flattened you.  So many bits of information, so little time, and no control. That's how it feels at first. but seriously, this does improve. It's maybe not the right terminology, but 'you will kind of get used to it'. The information will start to make sense, especially once your medical team set out a treatment plan for you.  My husband works 28/28, so I totally understand how you feel about sharing with him, when he is about to set off, or when you know he is away. It's difficult. And you don't want him to worry. - however, I am sure he will worry anyway, so you might as well share, and not keep him in the dark.  I have got a very close friend, who I confided in, whilst my OH was away. I had found my lump, and had to make all arrangements whist he was away. And I found it unbelievably helpful that my wonderful friend was there with me. She was detached enough, but totally caring. She came along to meetings, made lists, asked questions, and then after the meeting talked things through with me, as I was overwhelmed with all the info, and what it all meant.  My advice to you would be, take it all one step at a time, and if you can confide in a good friend, then go for it. let someone help you carry that weight just now.  And, do come here for questions and rants! people know what's going on inside you here.  Hugs,  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: newly diagnosed with DCIS queery invasive

Posts.Content: Hi Denise,  Congratulations! You have come such a long way already!  This thing is not a sprint, it's a marathon! And each lap/chemo session/bootcamp is reducing your resistance. This shit is wearing us down. Both physically and mentally. So, each time you have to summon up the courage to go for another session, it does get that bit harder!  What i hung onto was ticking off the ones I had already completed! And as the list of those became longer, and in comparison the list of those to be conquered was getting shorter, I felt I could manage those as well.  But, I do remember just crying as the last chemo session was in progress. It is so strange how the mind overruled any suggestion that I should not be doing this. I knew I had to. And yet, I watched as the poison was slowly running back into my veins, and I knew it was going to give me all those horrid side effects, again...  It does get tougher! But, you are getting there!!! And you have very bravely managed your treatment so far! Now you have to find those extra reserves! And hopefully find from other ladies here that coping with Tax is also doable! It is!  Huge hugs,  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Next stage chemo ... feeling nervous

Posts.Content: Hi Tinadeem, Yes, definitely a case of having it checked, and finding out what you can do to aid the recovery.  Not sure the picking of the crust is such a good way forward though. I am just recalling when my babies had the crust on their scalp, the best thing to do was to apply baby creams.  Let us know how you get on.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Nipple crusting

Posts.Content: Hey Sue, I feel I can hear from your comment that you are, although rightfully put off by your streak, you are handling it with humour. Congratulations for not letting it overwhelm you.  I am also hearing you appreciating the stress you have been under, and most probably still are under. I am wondering, like you, if this is stress related, and if so, whether it is just a delayed reaction by your body. As you are saying you have been in the torment since September. Maybe your body is only just really catching up to the News. You are only just 6 months down the line. That's still very early days!  And in that case, maybe there is a way of addressing your stress. A lot of it is very obvious, but then there might be hidden agendas, which cause you extra concern, like looking after loved ones, holding down your job etc.  I am not so sure about the regeneration of colour in your hair. It may be a case of making an appointment with the hair salon. But, have you got people around you to bounce your worries off to? Friends who make cups of tea and have boxes of tissues may come in very handy just now.  Big hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: GREY HAIR / TAMOXIFEN

Posts.Content: Oh, I am so sorry to hear you are having Round 2 of all this shite! That's pants. Hope you have plenty caring lovely people around you, who can help you along. It's what we are all scared of, isn't it?!  But they do say there is so much they can do, and if it means another round of bootcamp, well, then that's just got to be done!  Brave girl! Keep fighting those buggers!  Hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Secondary Breast Cancer with Bone and Lung Mets.......feeling very...

Posts.Content: Good morning Abbey, Sorry to hear you are having trouble with your shoulder. I must admit I did not have your symptom, so can't confirm anything.  But I would go have it checked out. Might just be localised side effect. I am wondering also though whether you sat awkwardly when the infusion was running, whether maybe you strained a nerve in your neck or upper back? And you may be getting referred pain.  Either case, no point worrying, because that usually makes us feel worse. And the docs may need to know about possible side effects anyway.  All the best, hope it improves soon. Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Sore/bruised feeling in shoulder a few days after 1st Herceptin.....

Posts.Content: Isn't it ridiculous how we cling to our hair. My son cut mine to a No1 and I held my hands over my eyes for the whole duration even though I wasn't even sitting in front of a mirror. My family keep saying I look lovely. But, I shall be very glad when I get to see even sprigs of hair regrowing now.  I so feel for you. But, having taken the plunge, you do have other options to play with now, and you don't have the strain of the cold cap and the worry as to how much it is going to work.  You are so brave for sharing your experience on here. I am sure there are loads of women who take comfort from your words.  How is the tax going now? Are you vertical again for a while?  Lots of love Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Got the hair clippers out this morning!

Posts.Content: Hey Bobby, Getting freaked out, I think, seems a very natural defence, when you are totally in the dark about what is happening to you. It is like free fall for you just now, because you haven't got a map of any kind as yet as to where you are heading.  On this site, I have found over and over the comments: don't go googling! And I think that is sound advice. For the reason, that your cancer is going to be very specific. The genetic detailing which they are going to find out about your tumour is going to help you in the long run with your treatment. But that is going to take a little more time, and you need to exercise some more patience - not a great word in my vocabulary, either!!!  Great shame you have been worried/anxious for such a long time, and are finding yourself not having been taken serious enough, soon enough??? - Don't dwell on it - maybe they were right then, maybe not - but, it's in the past. Let it go, if you can, because you are using up negative energy, and, boy, will you be needing a lot of positive energy from here on in!  Your path forward is going to be so much easier, I think, once you get some of your answers. Brace yourself for the diagnosis - that's shit to take! - But then you will be moving onto your treatment plan, and that's your first port of call, with regards: right, this is what I am dealing with, and this is what is going to be happening to me.  Take one step at a time, deep breath, and speak with your BC nurse!!! They are clever people, and she may ease you into your way forward, by answering questions, specific to your cancer, and to your situation.  And maybe you will be able to get good soundings off all these wonderful ladies here, too, who have been finding that these days 'there is soooo much that can be done' - due to amazing research advances, we are in such more capable hands here! Makes it a good grounding for a positive battleground!!! - Let your fight begin! Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: new and scared...

Posts.Content: Hi Kipper,  There IS strength in you: It's the strength of saying "I am struggling here"!  You have done bootcamp, which has flawed you, and you are still looking to need more healing strength to cope with your op. At this point bootcamp has left you run on empty! And not just physically, but also emotionally.  My op came first. And in some respects maybe that's easier, because after the surgeon had done his bit I felt "IT" was out and gone, and all I was left to cope with was the cleaning up business!  You, on the other hand still have that dark cloud hanging over you, wondering does it work, is the tumour shrinking? There are so many unknowns on this journey!  I am so glad you have found the courage to write it down. I would love to make contact via email, if you like. I have done my bootcamp, and my tanning. Just finishing my last few Herceptin. And I am here to tell the tale. If you fancy, pm me, and we can email.  Hugs, Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: My experience so far

Posts.Content: When i went into hospital - granted I only had a lumpectomy and lymph nodes - I took a cotton nighty with loooong straps, no sleeves. Dead easy to pull your arm out without lifting it.  Was also reading all the comments and was wondering about going for buttoned shirts instead. That way you get a much wider choice. Nobody need know that they aren't night clothes, and you can find pj bottoms anywhere.  Just a thought.  Dorothee x
