Posts.Title: My experience so far

Posts.Content: well done for finishing!! Yay!  I just wanted to point you to another group here, which you like to pop into, now that you have graduated from this one.  There is a group called Life after Cancer. And I think it highlights the fact that we feel very vulnerable and we encounter issues which we hadn't anticipated. But it's not a question any more as to how to get through bootcamp, and how do you do tanning. It's a case of how do you cope fitting back into your life? Why do people think I am 'fine' now? Why does my life not feel like it used to?  If you feel you are struggling with any of those, just make sure you know you can come back and share.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: All done

Posts.Content: hey Annie, good to hear from you!  I had a transfusion after my 4th FEC. Yes, I got colour too. But tbh I didn't feel a boost of energy. Sorry. But then, I didn't do tax.  Hope you have had a special day with your boys today. Lots of love Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: How long before you feel better after blood transfusion?

Posts.Content: Yay, Good luck on the night! Enjoy! Hope you have made a great job of decorating your bras!  I still have another month of 'training'! I am walking the Moonwalk in Edinburgh with my son!  It's a fantastic event, and in a not very small way for people like ourselves, it provides a focus to claw ourselves back out from the brink of near destruction!  The distance doesn't matter half as much as the fact you get to the starting line, and you feel you are ready to take this challenge on! (Did I say 'feel ready' ????)  All the best for tomorrow. have a brilliant time, and drink lots of sweet tea!!  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: Moonwalk - 10th May

Posts.Content: YES, it is statistical jargon. And in your case for childcare, I imagine it has to do with insurance policies.  A prognosis is a 'guesstimate' of what is possible/likely. But it is taken from the past history of many, many other people. It is not YOUR definite future, because we are all so very different. And our bodies cope differently with the challenges. And then there is treatment, which is always improving. We are in such a different position to people only about 10 or 20 years ago. And things are improving all the time.  Getting it in black and white is harsh, especially when you are feeling well and are coping well. Take a deep breather, and maybe have a chat with your BC nurse, to ease your worries, that you are not likely to keel over just yet. ;)  And good luck and all the best with your fostering. Takes a very special person to open your house and your heart to some very needy youngsters.  Dorothee xx
Posts.Title: What does prognosis mean?

Posts.Content: hi Linda, hard luck. Hope you haven't been too unwell.  I have had 2 excursions to hospital due to Neutropenia. And both times I just couldn't get the temp under control. But once the antibiotics were flowing things were fine.  First time round I had an incredibly sore mouth. Funnily enough the docs kept looking for the source of the infection, looking everywhere, and I kept telling them I have a bloody sore mouth! lol.  The second time round I was okay, once I got my antibiotics.  On both occasions my oncologist reviewed the dosage of my FEC. After the first Neutropenia the dosage was reduced to 70% on one of the ingredients. The other time was after No4, and he took out the F part altogether. Then I got bloods, and he said, if there was any more trouble he would stop the chemo altogether and move on to Herceptin earlier. Thankfully, all was fine though, and I finished the whole course. I guess the problem is that the dosage and ratios are measured purely by weight and height, and maybe by age. But that doesn't take into consideration anything personal such as fitness, metabolism, diet etc. We are all individuals, and the havoc which is supposed to be caused is therefore individually differently experienced.  I don't think you can do much to keep from getting Neutropenic. It is most likely your own bugs, which usually live in peace and harmony with you, that start aggravating you when your defence system is down. It will be your own bugs in your throat or elsewhere.  I would certainly think your oncologist should be having a chat with you as to how he is hoping to proceed from here. After all, the chemo is meant to be keeping you alive!! Not give you the rest!  but then you might just have been very unlucky and you may just sail through the rest from here on.  Good luck. Keep fingers crossed and the worst is done.  Dorothee xx
